item.title: Salix Updates Xifaxan Timelines [dis:IBS, dis:Diarrhoea]
item.description: Salix Updates Xifaxan Timelines [dis:IBS, dis:Diarrhoea]
item.content:encoded:
Salix Updates Xifaxan Timelines [:GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea, :GastroEnterology:dis:IBS]
GastroEnterology2159 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 December 2014 | 17:28

Comment: Management reported a delay of 3 months to May 27, 2015 in the approval of Xifaxan for IBS-D (a new indication expected to generate around $125-150mn in sales). In paralell, Salix stock rose more than 7% when the company announced it expects to reduce the inventory of XIFAXAN® 550, APRISO® and UCERIS® to 3 months by the end of 2015.
Rationale for the PDUFA Delay
Management outlined that the delay is strictly procedural, and was attributed to the “volume of data” that was submitted to the FDA, and a “lot of FDA interaction” around the NDA.
With 3 pivotal trials + microbiome data management believes the IBS submission does entail a substantial amount of data review.
Source: Leerink Partners; Sterne; Company's PR

item.title: Allergan Receives Reimbursement Approval In Italy For Botox To Treat Chronic Migraine
item.description: Allergan Receives Reimbursement Approval In Italy For Botox To Treat Chronic Migraine
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Receives Reimbursement Approval In Italy For Botox To Treat Chronic Migraine
Neurology7856 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 16 December 2014 | 17:13

Comment: Allergan has today announced that Botox has obtained authorisation from the AIFA for reimbursement in Italy for a new indication: symptomatic relief in adult patients who meet the diagnostic criteria for chronic migraine and have showed a poor response or are intolerant to drugs for prophylaxis.
Commenting on this approval Prof. Gennaro Bussone - Director Department of Clinical Neurosciences and the Unit for the diagnosis and treatment of Headache Foundation IRCCS - Carlo Besta Neurological Institute in Milan stated: "This is an important step in the treatment of migraine and chronic that it is hoped will lead to greater recognition of this form of headache that seriously compromises the quality of life of sufferers" - said - "treatment with BOTOX® has been shown to reduce the frequency of days with migraine, which results in significant benefits for patients. Patients with chronic migraine has long needed therapeutic approaches based on clinical studies with large series and this new therapeutic opportunity offers them a real chance of improvement, particularly for that category of patients significantly compromised by this disabling condition."
http://www.dossiermedicina.it/Website/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=64:botox%C2%AE-riceve-l%E2%80%99autorizzazione-dall%E2%80%99aifa-per-il-trattamento-profilattico-dell-emicrania-cronica&catid=11:news-sulla-salute-e-medici-on-line&Itemid=254

item.title: Interim Data Shows Sophiris' PRX302 May Not Be Effective for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms of BPH [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Interim Data Shows Sophiris' PRX302 May Not Be Effective for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms of BPH [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Interim Data Shows Sophiris' PRX302 May Not Be Effective for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms of BPH [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10164 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 December 2014 | 15:53

Comment: The Independent Data Monitoring Committee reported that a predefined efficacy threshold following treatment was not achieved. Those findings came from an administrative interim analysis of efficacy in the ongoing Ph3 "PLUS-1" trial. Sophiris lost about 80% of its market value.
PRX302 (topsalysin) is an injectable intraprostatic therapy, and is designed to be administered by a urologist.
Next Milestones
The complete 12 month data analysis are expected in the second half of 2015.
Clinical Trials
About the PLUS-1 Trial
The Ph3 "PLUS-1" study is an international, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, and vehicle-controlled trial to assess the safety and efficacy of a single intraprostatic administration of PRX302 (0.6 µg/g prostate) for the treatment of BPH.
Enrollment and dosing in the study were completed in September 2014.
The primary endpoint is the IPSS total score change from baseline over 52 weeks.
Secondary endpoints include Qmax (maximum urine flow) change from baseline over 52 weeks.
Source: Sophiris

item.title: Signifor LAR Approved In US For Acromegaly [prod:Pasireotide]
item.description: Signifor LAR Approved In US For Acromegaly [prod:Pasireotide]
item.content:encoded:
Signifor LAR Approved In US For Acromegaly [:Endocrinology:prod:Pasireotide]
Endocrinology7887 | Posted by Giorgia VICENTINI | 16 December 2014 | 15:32

Comment: Following the EU approval on November 24th, Novartis has gained FDA approval for Signifor LAR, an injectable suspension for intramuscular use for the treatment of patients with acromegaly who have had an inadequate response to surgery and/or for whom surgery is not an option.
Signifor LAR has orphan drug designation for acromegaly in the US, only granted to products treating a condition that affects less than 200,000 people in the US, and securing seven-year market exclusivity. The approval is supported by two Phase III clinical studies, C2305 and C2402 (PAOLA) proving efficacy in medically naïve patients and those inadequately controlled on standard of care. According to Novartis Press Release, the safety and efficacy profile of Signifor LAR has not yet been established in counties outside the US or the EU in patients with acromegaly. It is mentioned that "for various reasons, including the uncertainty of the clinical trials, there is no guarantee Signifor LAR will become commercially available anywhere else in the world".
The approval is line with Ipsen expectations and further details can be found at the link to MyEndoCommunity, including a franchise statement and strategy to respond to Signifor approval in EU and US.
Source: Novartis Press Release

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: giv91620

item.title: Novartis Buys 12.8% Stake in BioLineRx [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD]
item.description: Novartis Buys 12.8% Stake in BioLineRx [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD]
item.content:encoded:
Novartis Buys 12.8% Stake in BioLineRx [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD]
PharmaWorld11043 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 December 2014 | 15:01

Comment: Under the agreement, Novartis, which invested an initial $10M (and acquired an initial 5M American depositary shares of BioLineRx in a private transaction at $2.00 a share), will evaluate projects presented by BioLineRX for development and future licensing. The clinical-stage, publicly-traded biopharma development company was founded in 2003 by Teva and other key players in Israeli Life Sciences Industry. Amongs a pipeline of 10 assets, it is developing BL-7040 a novel, orally available synthetic oligonucleotide for the treatment of IBD (currently in Ph2a).
Agreement Focused on Project
Once a project is selected, Novartis will pay BioLineRx an option fee of $5 million and fund half the remaining development costs in the form of an additional equity investment in BioLineRx.
Recent Newsflow from BioLine RX
BioLineRx has provided critical updates on key pipeline projects in recent weeks.
  • It now plans to test a larger cohort at higher doses in its Phase II trial of BL-8040 in acute myeloid leukaemia on the back of encouraging efficacy/safety data presented at the ASH conference this week.
  • Enrolment for the CE mark trial of Bioabsorbable Cardiac Matrix is expected to be completed by year end and study completion is slated for mid-2015.
  • BioLineRx also recently announced positive Phase I/II safety data for BL-7010 in coeliac disease, enabling the start of a pivotal efficacy trial in 2015
Pipeline

item.title: New Structure Announced Following the Acquisition of Allergan [comp:Allergan]
item.description: New Structure Announced Following the Acquisition of Allergan [comp:Allergan]
item.content:encoded:
New Structure Announced Following the Acquisition of Allergan [:Neurology:comp:Allergan]
Neurology7853 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 December 2014 | 14:08

Comment: The combined company is expected to have >two dozen mid-and near-term products in development, and will have commercial operations in >100 countries, and a more "complex combined portfolio of brand products". As President & CEO, Brent Saunders will be leading a team of leaders from both Actavis and Allergan. An overview of the new organization is provided below.
Commercial Business
Global brand S&M will be structured into 3 organizations: International Brands, Branded Pharma and Allergan Medical.
  • Paul Navarre, Allergan Corporate Vice President and President Europe, Africa and the Middle East, will become Executive Vice President Actavis, and President, International Brands.
  • William Meury, Actavis Executive Vice President for North American Brands will become Executive Vice President Actavis, and President, Branded Pharma with responsibility for Eye Care, Neurosciences, Gastroenterology, Urology, Women's Health and other Specialty brand portfolios.
  • Philippe Schaison, Allergan Corporate Vice President, President Allergan Medical, will become Executive Vice President Actavis, President Allergan Medical, which will include Facial Aesthetics, Medical Dermatology, Plastic Surgery and SkinMedica. These individuals will report directly to Mr. Saunders.
Brand R&D
  • Will be led by Actavis' C. David Nicholson, PhD, Senior Vice President, Global Brand R&D in the role of Executive Vice President, Branded R&D. (Dr. Nicholson will report directly to Mr. Saunders).
Generics and Global Operations
  • Robert Stewart, currently Actavis' Chief Operating Officer, will become Executive Vice President Actavis, and President, Generics and Global Operations. (He will report directly to Mr. Saunders).
Source: http://finance.yahoo.com/news/actavis-announces-proposed-senior-leadership-123000490.html; http://www.actavis.com/news/news/thomson-reuters/actavis-announces-proposed-senior-leadership-t-(1)

item.title: Valneva's C.difficile Vaccine to Enter POC Trial [:GastroEnterology:news, sub:ClinicalTrial, mkt:Germany, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.description: Valneva's C.difficile Vaccine to Enter POC Trial [:GastroEnterology:news, sub:ClinicalTrial, mkt:Germany, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.content:encoded:
Valneva's C.difficile Vaccine to Enter POC Trial [:GastroEnterology:news, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Germany, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
PharmaWorld11041 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 15 December 2014 | 18:52

Comment: Valneva, formed in 2013 through the merger of Intercell AG and Vivalis SA, is a biotech company developing, manufacturing and commercializing vaccines. Its vaccine candidate for C.difficile is a recombinant protein vaccine consisting of two truncated toxins A and B from C.difficile.The trial will take place in the US and Germany, and recruit approx 500 subjects. PE will measure seroconversion rate (SCR) on D56. GSK has got opt-in rights if Ph2 successful.

About the Ph2

ID: NCT02316470
Timelines: Start date Dec 2014 - Completion date May 2015 / October 2015

Ph1 Results

In Sept 2013, Valneva announced positive Ph1 results (favorable safety and tolerabilityprofile in both elderly subjects and adults).
Vaccine Profile / Position

Comments
Valneva SE has reported that its VLA84 vaccine met the primary endpoint in a Ph2 study to prevent Clostridium difficile infection. The study included 500 healthy volunteers who received a 75 µg intramuscular vaccine dose without an alum adjuvant, a 200 µg dose with or without the adjuvant, or placebo, administered at days 0, 7 and 28. Valneva said the vaccine induced immune responses to both C. difficiletoxins A and B at all doses, and said the 200 µg dose without alum led to the highest seroconversion rate against both toxins A and B on day 56. Next development steps to be announced after final study close-out in Q2 2016 and consultations with regulators and Partner.
The key objectives of this Phase II trial have been met, the vaccine candidate generated strong immune responses against C. difficile toxins A and B, and the safety and tolerability profile was good.
Valneva´s vaccine candidate is targeting the prevention of primary symptomatic C.difficile infection (CDI).
The vaccine is designed to produce an immune response to neutralize the effects of C. difficile toxins A and B, considered to be largely responsible for CD
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / PharmaWorld11329 / 01 December 2015 / 09:00:09 o'clock CET

item.title: Interesting New Approach To The Treatment of Huntington's Disease [dis:Huntington]
item.description: Interesting New Approach To The Treatment of Huntington's Disease [dis:Huntington]
item.content:encoded:
Interesting New Approach To The Treatment of Huntington's Disease [:Neurology:dis:Huntington]
Neurology7851 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 15 December 2014 | 18:47

Comment: Novartis Venture Fund has stepped in to take the lead on a $34 million venture round for Redwood City, Annexon Bioscience, which believes it has the inside track on a new autoimmunity approach to treating Huntington's disease.
Dr. Campbell Murray of Novartis Venture Funds has stated "Annexon has what we believe to be a uniquely elegant approach to neurodegenerative and autoimmune diseases. The important role of the classical complement cascade in antibody-mediated autoimmune disorders has been known for some time, and the discovery that it contributes to loss of nerve connections in neurodegenerative disease is highly innovative."
A protein called C1q, which initiates an immune response called the “complement cascade” that rids the brain of dead cells or bacteria, accumulates at junctions where nerve cells meet in the brain. Results recently published in the Journal of Neuroscience, indicates that elevated levels of C1q at these contact points, or synapses, may prime the junctions for death by the very immune cells meant to protect them.
Source: Fiercebiotech

OPKO and Pfizer Enter intoWW Agreement for OPKO’s LA Human Growth Hormone [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone, :Endocrinology:comp:Pfizer, :Endocrinology:dis:GrowthHormoneDeficiency, :Endocrinology:prod:Genotropin]
Endocrinology7885 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 15 December 2014 | 17:49

Comment: OPKO to receive upfront payment of $295 million, and eligible to receive up to an additional $275 million upon achievement of regulatory milestones. hGH-CTP is currently in a global Ph3 in adults and a global Ph2 in children. It has orphan drug designation in the U.S. and Europe for both adults and children with GHD.
Drug SnapShot
Rationale
Novo and Pfizer lead the daily GH business, with approx 1/4 of the market each.
Till this deal with OPKO Pfizer had no LA in development in its pipeline whereas Novo's LA drug is ongoing Ph3 for AGHD.
Additional Terms
OPKO will lead the clinical activities and will be responsible for funding the development programs for the key indications, which includes Adult and Pediatric GHD and Pediatric SGA.
Pfizer will be responsible for all development costs for additional indications as well as all post-marketing studies.
In addition, Pfizer will fund the commercialization activities for all indications and lead the manufacturing activities covered by the global development plan.

item.title: Sosei Acquires Leading Japanese Peptide Tech Company [headline, mkt:Japan]
item.description: Sosei Acquires Leading Japanese Peptide Tech Company [headline, mkt:Japan]
item.content:encoded:
Sosei Acquires Leading Japanese Peptide Tech Company [:PharmaWorld:headline, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
PharmaWorld11039 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 December 2014 | 09:14

Comment: Jitsubo, established in April 2005, is focused on development of peptide generic products and identification of new drug candidates based on the novel peptide synthesis technology, Molecular HivingTM, and the molecule modification technology, Peptune. This acquisition will enable Sosei to enter the peptide market.
Rationale of the Acquisition for Sosei
- Replenishing the existing pipeline with new peptide products to further enhance corporate value.
The press release mentions that there are currently over 50 marketed peptide products, and the peptide market is expected to reach $23 billion by 2020. Through the acquisition of Jitsubo the Group acquires a state-of-the-art technology that has a potential to become a generator of future revenue and growth.
About the Technologies
Molecular Hiving™: Molecular HivingTM technology is Jitsubo’s patented technology for a novel liquid-phase peptide synthesis. Currently, two types of peptide synthesis technologies are widely used: solid-phase peptide synthesis (SPPS) and liquid-phase peptide synthesis (LPPS). SPPS is a high cost technology often applied for the small scale manufacturing, whereas LPPS is often applied for larger scale manufacturing, but cannot be used for long-chain peptide synthesis. Molecular HivingTM technology combines the benefits of both SPPS and LPPS, and provides the solution for efficient peptide synthesis at low costs. Moreover, since the monitoring of peptide synthesis process that was not possible with SPPS was enabled with this technology, high-quality peptide can be manufactured more easily than with the currently existing methods.
Peptune™: PeptuneTM is a novel technology that enables arbitrary alteration of molecular configuration, without changing the amino acid sequence within the peptide. Compared to the existing similar technologies, it has a high structural diversity, which makes possible for pharmacological function and stability to be improved based on the molecular configuration of peptide. In addition, introducing a new functional molecule to a cross-linkage is also possible, and this new scientific approach enables the production of novel functional peptide

item.title: Allergan Study Reveals The The Trend To Look Younger Is Changing [news, sub:Aesthetics]
item.description: Allergan Study Reveals The The Trend To Look Younger Is Changing [news, sub:Aesthetics]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Study Reveals The The Trend To Look Younger Is Changing [:Neurology:news, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7848 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 12 December 2014 | 08:43

Comment: Allergan has recently completed a 2000 subject study evaluating our attitudes to ageing and reportedly to its surprise found that we don't want to look 10 years younger anymore. A "gentle softening" appears to be the favoured look.
The study was undertaken as a social experiment to guage our emerging attitudes to anti-aging
To test opinnions, researchers took a photo of five women in their early fifities and went onto to retouch the image to two varying degress- one version undergoing total wrinkle-eradication , while the other image underwnet a "gentle softening" procedurs. The images were then evaluated by 2000 individulas comprising the over 18 all-female panel.
Key Findings
  • Unanimous vote for the "gentle softened" version although two thirds of the women went on to admit they thought each subject looked better with her wrinkles.
  • The five women whose photos were used also agreed that they preferred the image of themselves whey they kept their wrinkles. They just did not want to look totally flawless as that was considered not realistic for their age.
Honey Lancaster-James, behavioural psychologist who assessed the results of the study. "What's really interesting is that women today don't want to look years younger, they want to age well which for them, means looking great for their age,"
The results flagged up the fact that 69 per cent of the panel pointed out that a "gentle softening" effect had left the fifty-something participants looking more refreshed.
According to plastic surgeon Dr Jonquilee Chantrey. "More people are choosing less invasive treatments with dermal fillers, as it's possible to achieve a very natural and refreshed look.
Source http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG11287823/Study-by-Botox-makers-reveals-we-dont-want-to-look-younger.html

item.title: First Report Of Clinical Activity With A New CRF-1 antagonist in Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia [news]
item.description: First Report Of Clinical Activity With A New CRF-1 antagonist in Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia [news]
item.content:encoded:
First Report Of Clinical Activity With A New CRF-1 antagonist in Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia [:Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7882 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 11 December 2014 | 17:55

Comment: Neurocrine Biosciences announced today the start of a new clinical programme with a proprietary CRF-1 antagonist NBI-77860 to address congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).The Company has successfully completed a pilot clinical trial in adults with classic CAH and is initiating an open-label, single ascending dose trial in approximately fifteen adolescent females with classic CAH.
What is NBI-77860 & What Advantages May It Offer Versus Today''s Therapy?
NBI-77860 is a potent, selective non-peptide CRF receptor antagonist as demonstrated in a range of in vitro/in vivo assays and human clinical studies. Blockade of CRF receptors at the pituitary has been shown to decrease the release of ACTH, which in turn decreases the production of adrenal steroids including androgens, and potentially the symptoms associated with classic CAH. Lower ACTH levels would also reduce the amount of exogenous corticosteroid necessary for classic CAH patients to thrive avoiding the side-effects currently associated with excessive steroid therapy
Commenting on this development Christopher F. O'Brien, Chief Medical Officer stated "We are very pleased with the results from our pilot study of NBI-77860 in patients that was conducted earlier this year and excited to add another significant program to our clinical development pipeline. We have requested orphan drug status from the FDA while we continue to expand our preclinical and clinical efforts around NBI-77860 in classic CAH."
Meanwhile, Dr. Richard Auchus, Professor of Internal Medicine, Division of Metabolism, Endocrinology & Diabetes at University of Michigan Health System has noted that. "This treatment strategy, if validated in future clinical trials, has the potential to revolutionize the treatment for CAH patients and make an important difference in their lives."
Results from the Initial Pilot Clinical Study

The pilot clinical trial was a blinded, single-site, pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic study assessing two single, ascending doses of NBI-77860 against placebo in adult females with refractory CAH. The eight study participants visited the investigative site for three separate overnight visits consisting of bedtime dosing with placebo or one of two active doses of NBI-77860. Each of the visits was separated by a three-week washout period. Key biomarker measurements included adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP), androgen, and cortisol levels collected in the morning after dosing. Data from this initial single dose exploratory study demonstrated a robust decrease in ACTH and 17-OHP.
A full description of the study results and related data will be presented at an upcoming scientific meeting.
1401 Study Design
The 1401 study is a Phase I/II open-label, sequential cohort, single ascending dose pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic study assessing three doses of NBI-77860. The fifteen adolescent females with classic CAH will be split into three cohorts and each will receive one dose of NBI-77860 at bedtime. Biomarker measurements include ACTH, 17-OHP, androgen, and cortisol levels collected the morning after dosing.
What Is CAH?

Neurocrine Biosciences Development Profile

Comments
Neurocrine Biosciences has announced that the steering committee of ENDO 2015 has selected the abstract of their recently completed clinical study of NBI-77860 in classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia for an oral presentation on the initial day of the Endocrine Society's 97th Annual Meeting. The presentation will take place on Thursday, March 5, 2015 from 11:30 am to 1:00 pm (PST) during the session entitled "HPA Axis and Adrenal: Receptors to Clinical Impact."
 
Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK / Endocrinology7929 / 27 January 2015 / 10:11:51 o'clock CET
This is an interesting approach from the endocrinological perspective. The patients will still, however, need to take hydrocortisone replacement therapy. The advantage of Chronocort is that it does both - controls ACTH secretion and also provides replacement therapy. Chronocort is also going into Phase III, so it is way ahead
Philip HARRIS / Endocrinology7935 / 28 January 2015 / 14:36:39 o'clock CET
Neurocrine Biosciences has announced on February 17th an underwritten public offering of shares to raise $225M to fund its R&D efforts as well for preparing for commercialization of its lead assets.
Giorgia VICENTINI / Endocrinology7967 / 18 February 2015 / 16:21:05 o'clock CET

item.title: BioGaia Lactobacillus reuteri Effective in Constipated Adults [dis:Constipation, sub:Probiotics]
item.description: BioGaia Lactobacillus reuteri Effective in Constipated Adults [dis:Constipation, sub:Probiotics]
item.content:encoded:
BioGaia Lactobacillus reuteri Effective in Constipated Adults [:GastroEnterology:dis:Constipation, :GastroEnterology:sub:Probiotics]
GastroEnterology2154 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 11 December 2014 | 15:34

Comment: A recent randomized controlled trial (RCT) showed a positive effect of Lactobacillus reuteri on bowel movement frequency in infants with chronic constipation. The aim of the present study was to evaluate the effects of L. reuteri in adult patients with functional constipation. Findings show that the patients given Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis were less constipated after 4 weeks compared to patients given placebo.
About the Study
Principal investigator Dr Veronica Ojetti, Department of Medical Sciences, Division of Gastroenterology, Catholic University Rome, Italy.
Study design A randomised, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial in 40 adult patients diagnosed with functional constipation according to the Rome III criteria. The patients were randomly assigned to supplementation with two chewable tablets of either Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis (2x108 cfu, n=20) or corresponding placebo (n=20) daily for 28 days.
Outcome parameters Primary outcome was increase of bowel movements per week. Secondary outcome was improvement of stool consistency
Location: Gastro Unit of the Catholic U. of Rome (Italy)
Reference
The Effect of Lactobacillus reuteri Supplementation in Adults with Chronic Functional Constipation: a Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial Journal of Gastrointestinal and Liver Diseases Veronica Ojetti, Gianluca Ianiro, Annalisa Tortora, Giovanna D'Angelo, Teresa Antonella Di Rienzo, Stefano Bibbo, Alessio Migneco, Antonio Gasbarrini http://dx.doi.org/10.15403/jgld.2014.1121.234.elr

item.title: AstraZeneca's Opioid-Induced Constipation Drug Cleared in EU [dis:Constipation, news]
item.description: AstraZeneca's Opioid-Induced Constipation Drug Cleared in EU [dis:Constipation, news]
item.content:encoded:
AstraZeneca's Opioid-Induced Constipation Drug Cleared in EU [:GastroEnterology:dis:Constipation, :GastroEnterology:news]
GastroEnterology2153 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 10 December 2014 | 19:03

Comment: Moventig (naloxegol) is the first once-daily peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist (PAMORA) to be approved in the EU, according to AstraZeneca, and has been approved to constipation in patients who do not respond to laxative therapy. The company intends to launch naloxegol in both the US and EU by the end of Q1 201 or early in Q2 2015.
US Status
FDA approved AZ's Movantik in September 2014 for chronic non-cancer pain suffering from opioid-induced constipation
Drug Design
Naloxegol is designed to selectively block mu opioid receptors in the gastrointestinal tract - preventing constipation - while staying out of the central nervous system so pain relief is unaffected.
Source: Pmlive; AstraZeneca; Nektar Therapeutics

item.title: New Report Highlights An Improving Picture In Terms Of Returns From Pharmaceutical R&D [func:RnD, news]
item.description: New Report Highlights An Improving Picture In Terms Of Returns From Pharmaceutical R&D [func:RnD, news]
item.content:encoded:
New Report Highlights An Improving Picture In Terms Of Returns From Pharmaceutical R&D [:PharmaWorld:func:RnD, :PharmaWorld:news]
PharmaWorld11033 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 10 December 2014 | 13:07

Comment: Today Deloitte's in collaboration with Thomson Reuters have released a report highlighting the return from pharmaceutical innovation. It is entitiled "Weathering The Storm" and suggests that Pharmaceutical R&D returns are turning a corner. Overall returns have improved to 5.5% this year compared to 5.1% in 2013 with the FDA having approved 35 new products this year up from 27 overall in 2013 and close to the bumper 39 cleared in 2012.
Methodology
For the last four years Deloitte and Thomson Reuters have analysed the performance of the top 12 life sciences companies by estimating the projected financial returns from the investment in their late stage pipelines.
The cohort of companies comprises the 12 companies reporting the highest absolute research and development (R&D) spend for 2008-2009. The late stage pipeline includes those compounds which are either in Phase III development or submitted for approval.
Key Findings
This year’s research highlights are as follows:-
  • the top 12 companies have launched 105 products since 2010, with a projected value of $770 billion
  • since 2010, 167 compounds have been pulled into late stage development with a total risk-adjusted value of $819 billion
  • the cost of bringing an asset from discovery to launch increased by 18%, rising from $1.1 billion in 2010 to $1.3 billion in 2013
  • late stage terminations continue to take too much value out of company pipelines, amounting to a loss of $243 billion over the four years
  • the average forecast for the peak sales of an asset declined by 43%, dropping from $816 million in 2010 to $466 million in 2013.
A copy of the report is freely downloadable from the following site
http://www2.deloitte.com/view/en_GB/uk/research-and-intelligence/deloitte-research-uk/deloitte-uk-centre-for-health-solutions/pharmaceutical-innovation-2013/index.html

Add a Comment on this Article

item.description: Update on Ph3 Study of PROSTVAC® for mCRPC [class:Vaccines, dis:Prostate, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Update on Ph3 Study of PROSTVAC® for mCRPC [:Oncology:class:Vaccines, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Oncology10161 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 10 December 2014 | 12:13

Comment: Bavarian Nordic has reported it has reached the planned enrollment of 1,200 patients (214 sites in 15 countries). The company has 4 other ongoing NCI-sponsored studies assessing PROSTVAC® in different indications of prostate cancer (see details below). Last November, alongside the financial results for the first nine months of 2014, management highlighted that contract negotiations on partnering PROSTVAC® were ongoing.
PROSTVAC® Ongoing Studies
About the PROSPECT Trial
Ref ID NCT01322490
All countries active: Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Iceland, Israel, Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Spain, UK & US.

item.title: Pierre Fabre Unveils Strategy to 2018 [func:RnD, mkt:France]
item.description: Pierre Fabre Unveils Strategy to 2018 [func:RnD, mkt:France]
item.content:encoded:
Pierre Fabre Unveils Strategy to 2018 [:PharmaWorld:func:RnD, :PharmaWorld:mkt:France]
PharmaWorld11029 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 10 December 2014 | 11:01

Comment: Pierre Fabre, the third-largest French pharmaceutical laboratory, aims to cut costs in pharmaceuticals to build a consumer healthcare franchise and grow its dermo-cosmetics business (particularly in Asia and the US). By 2016, 551 jobs will be cut in R&D, almost in France. Sanofi made the same reproach to his company's R&D site in Toulouse in 2012, and finally agreed last week to hand over the site to Evotec. Management hopes its plan will give it financial firepower to buy new drugs from other companies
Dermo-Cosmetics Division
Accounts for 55% of group revenue and the bulk of its profit (whereas the pharmaceuticals division has seen sales fall in France since 2009, hit by deficit-reduction measures that have weighed on drug prices).
R&D Focus
Management said it would focus its R&D on oncology, neuropsychiatry and dermatology.
Traction Reference
See PharmaWorld11023: Sanofi in Talks toTransfer its Toulouse R&D Site to Evotec

item.title: Antisense To Evaluate Higher Doses For Inclusion In PhIII Study & Partnering Opportunities [dis:Acromegaly, news]
item.description: Antisense To Evaluate Higher Doses For Inclusion In PhIII Study & Partnering Opportunities [dis:Acromegaly, news]
item.content:encoded:
Antisense To Evaluate Higher Doses For Inclusion In PhIII Study & Partnering Opportunities [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7880 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 09 December 2014 | 16:52

Comment: Antisense Therapeutics issued a press release today relating to its ongoing partnering process for ATL1103, scheduled to reach a definitive agreement between March & May next year. Additionally, it has announced plans to undertake a small, higher dose (600mg/week) study in 4 acromegalic patients to support the use of a higher doses in its phIII trials for patients with more aggressive disease.
Regarding The Additional Dose Cohort
The trial application has been submitted, with the Ethics Committee response anticipated by the end of this calendar year. Given the relatively low cost of this trial and its eligibility for the 45% R&D tax incentive, and in order to keep the drug’s development on track, ANP will conduct this additional trial in parallel with the partnering process outlined.
It envisages that the trial will add further value to ATL1103 ahead of the Phase III registration trials which would be conducted with a pharmaceutical partner
Regarding Partnering
Antisense Therapeutics notes that it has escalated its partnering activities following publication of its phII results.
It is is working closely with US based specialist advisory firm Destum Partners on this process, which it claims is now well advanced and has reached due diligence phase with a number of interested parties.
Destum and ANP are aiming to complete this process to attract a suitable partner and progress into the definitive agreement within the next three to six months.
Source: www.antisesensetherapeutics.com

item.title: The First ‘Carcinoid NETs Mobile App’ to Become Available in Early 2015 [:PharmaWorld:sub:Devices]
item.description: The First ‘Carcinoid NETs Mobile App’ to Become Available in Early 2015 [:PharmaWorld:sub:Devices]
item.content:encoded:
The First ‘Carcinoid NETs Mobile App’ to Become Available in Early 2015 [:PharmaWorld:sub:Devices]
Endocrinology7877 | Posted by Giorgia VICENTINI | 09 December 2014 | 15:20

Comment: The Carcinoid Cancer Foundation and Self Care Catalyst, a patient intelligence health solution provider, have announced a new partnership on December 8th to launch a new mobile phone app to support patients that have been diagnosed with carcinoids tumours and NETs, including pNETs. Creating an app for carcinoid NETs will address the need of patients that, when first diagnosed, turn into technology to understand how the disease will impact into their life and what is the treatment path. More, the app will be an invaluable tool for patients to organize their life. share experiences, and take information with them on the move such as medications intake, symptoms list and bloodwork results to improve communication with their healthcare providers. It will also give access to physicians to understand the day-to-day struggles and behaviors of NET cancer patients.
"We are very excited to partner with Self Care Catalysts to empower carcinoid and NET patients" says Keith Warner, CEO of the Carcinoid Cancer Foundation. "By providing the Carcinoid NETs app to the NET community, we will share an extremely valuable resource. It's critical for individuals who are living with a rare disease to have a wide variety of resources. These include identifying physicians who specialize in treating with carcinoid /NET, creating support circles, learning about treatment options, and accessing clinical trials. Additionally, by gathering information from patients and their loves ones, we can further identify and help to meet the needs of the community".
The app will become available free of charge in early 2015 through computers and mobiles and downloadable from the Google Play and the Apple Store.
This app comes after the first global survey of patients with NET revealed that 41% of patients believe that a better understanding of how to manage their disease-related symptoms would help them live a better life. 60% of patients also revealed their emotional health is affected by having NETs. The survey was sponsored by Novartis and INCA and fielded from February to May 2014. Results were reported in October 2014 (flyer enclosed). You can also find the survey results at the following link.
Source: Yahoo finance, Carcinoid Cancer Foundation and Self Care Catalysts

item.title: Merck Acquires Cubist Pharmaceuticals Strengthening its Position in Antibiotics [sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Merck Acquires Cubist Pharmaceuticals Strengthening its Position in Antibiotics [sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Merck Acquires Cubist Pharmaceuticals Strengthening its Position in Antibiotics [:PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
PharmaWorld11026 | Posted by Giorgia VICENTINI | 09 December 2014 | 12:51

Comment: Merck & Company has agreed on Monday 8th December to acquire Cubist Pharmaceuticals for £ 8.4 billion, plus the assumption of $ 1.1 billion in debt. Merck will pay $ 102 a share in cash for Cubist, a 35% premium above Cubist's average share price for the five most recent trading days. This deal fits with Merck's strategy of acquiring mid-sized pharmaceutical companies with more focused portfolios to complement its existing products.
Cubicin, Cubist bigger seller (annual sales around $1 billion) will integrate nicely into Merck's hospital division, one of its four prioritized business areas. This deal establishes Merck as the second largest American drug make after Pfizer to control the antibiotics landscape, ensuring deeper ties into the hospital care. Also, it reinforces how pharmaceutical companies are becoming committed to the antibiotics area again, especially after the FDA started offering incentives to manufacturers investing in new antibiotics products.
The acquisition is supposed to close in the first quarter of 2015.
Source: FierceBiotech

item.title: Second Company Sponsored Anti-PD1 Combination Trial In mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Second Company Sponsored Anti-PD1 Combination Trial In mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Second Company Sponsored Anti-PD1 Combination Trial In mCRPC [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10155 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 09 December 2014 | 11:21

Comment: Advaxis announced acceptance of its IND application and therefore commencing Ph1/2 clinical trials of their ADXS-PSA in combination with MSD's pembrolizumab (anti-PD1) for mCRPC patients. This clinical trial will be the first-in-human study of Advaxis's lead Lm-LLO immunotherapy product candidate in prostate cancer, which is expected to begin patient enrolment in Q1 2015. ADXS-PSA is designed to target the PSA and to inhibit the Treg and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs).
The Phase 1 part of the study will be a dose-escalating study designed to establish the maximum tolerated dose of ADXS-PSA when used alone and in combination with KEYTRUDA. The Phase 2 portion will assess the safety and efficacy of the combination immunotherapy regimen. Advaxis and Merck will collaboratively oversee the conduct of the study and will use the results from the trial to determine the future clinical development program for the combination.
Currently there are three combination immunotherapy combination in mCRPC:
Intervention (anti-PD-1 + Other Immuno-modulating agents) Trial Title Trial Status Trial Phase Sponsor Name Primary IDs Trial Start Date Trial End Date Data Monitoring Committee # of Subjects Planned
Pidilizumab (CureTech/Medivation) + Sipuleucel-T (Dendreon) + Cyclophosphamide Sipuleucel-T, CT-011, and Cyclophosphamide for Advanced Prostate Cancer Ongoing, recruiting Phase II Georgia Regents University NCT01420965 01-Sep-2012 01-Dec-2016 Yes 57
Pembrolizumab (MSD) + ADXS-PSA (Advaxis) Phase I/II Clinical Study of ADXS-PSA as Monotherapy and in Combination with Pembrolizumab in Subjects with Previously Treated Metastatic, Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer Planned Phase I/II Advaxis, Inc.   01-Jan-2015 TBD No  
Nivolumab (BMS) + Lirilumab (BMS) A Phase I Study of an Anti-KIR Antibody in Combination with an Anti-PD1 Antibody in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumours Ongoing, recruiting Phase I Bristol-Myers Squibb Company NCT01714739 01-Oct-2012 01-Sep-2017 No 162
Source: Advaxis Company Press Release, PharmaeTrack 2014 December

item.title: Takeda and Monash U. Form Strategic Alliance to Advance Research on New Therapies for GI Diseases [dis:IBD, news]
item.description: Takeda and Monash U. Form Strategic Alliance to Advance Research on New Therapies for GI Diseases [dis:IBD, news]
item.content:encoded:
Takeda and Monash U. Form Strategic Alliance to Advance Research on New Therapies for GI Diseases [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :GastroEnterology:news]
GastroEnterology2151 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 December 2014 | 10:24

Comment: Irritable bowel syndrome, abdominal pain, chronic itch, severe constipation and diarrhea will be the focus of the research alliance.
About the Alliance
Will be funded by Takeda
Pf Nigel Bunnett (Deputy Director , Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences) together with Dr Daniel Poole, also from MIPS, will lead the three-year research program.
Recent Update of Takeda in Gastro
Takeda’s gastroenterology Drug Discovery Unit is a highly specialized research team that works collaboratively with academic and industry partners. The team is actively seeking to leverage the best scientific and pharmaceutical expertise all over the world.
  • Q2:14 Launch of Entyvio for IBD and marketing of the drug in EU. The drug is perceived as a groundbreaking new product that offers new treatment options to paient with the disease who failed to respond to treatment with existingproducts. It is anticipated to be a blockbuster global product for the company.
  • Q4:14 Acquisition of Amitiza rights beyond the US and Canada to all global markets (except Japan and China).
Pipeline
  • Norovirous Vaccine (prevention of acute gastroenteritis cause by norovirus) in Ph2
  • TAK-114 (ulcerative colitis) in Ph2 US/EU and Ph1/Jpn
Source: Takeda
About Monash University
Monash University is Australia's largest university and ranked in the Top 100 World Universities according to the Times Higher Education World University Rankings.
The Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Science (MIPS) is Australia’s largest pharmaceutical sciences research program in translational drug discovery, drug delivery and drug development. Pharmacy and Pharmacology at Monash is ranked number one in the Asia-Pacific and top 10 worldwide (2014 QS World University Rankings).

item.title: Millennium Is Now Rebranded As "The Takeda Oncology Company"
item.description: Millennium Is Now Rebranded As "The Takeda Oncology Company"
item.content:encoded:
Millennium Is Now Rebranded As "The Takeda Oncology Company"
Oncology10153 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 08 December 2014 | 18:15

Comment:In June,Takeda suffered a setback when the company ended development of orteronel. Takeda re-focuses itself to re-form an Oncology Business Unit, formerly known as "Millennium", to "Takeda Oncology Company". This unit originated from a $8 billion acquisition in 2008. Currently Takeda's cancer portfolio is led by Velcade for multiple myeloma (US) which enjoyed a 13.3% jump in product sales during the first 6 months of the company's 2014 fiscal year. Closed behind in sales is leuprorelin racked up $507.6 million in April-Sept 2014, down 6% from a year earlier.
Takeda's cancer portfolio also includes two investigational compounds. One is Alsertib (MLN8237) an oral, selective, inhibitor of Aurora A kinase, which has been shown to be overexpressed in a variety of cancers. Alsertib is being explored for a wide range of blood malignancies and solid tumours, including relapsed or refractory peripheral T-cell lymphoma recurrent ovarian cancer, and small cell lung cancer. The other compound is Ixazomib (MLN9708), now under study in multiple myeloma (MM), systemic light-chain (AL) amyloidosis, and other malignancies.
Just last week, Ixazomib won Breakthrough Therapy status from the FDA for the systemic light-chain (AL) amyloidosis indication. Data used to support the designation is being presented at the American Society of Hematology (ASH) annual meeting set for December 6-9 in San Francisco.
The first oral proteasome inhibitor to enter Phase III clinical trials, Ixazomib is being assessed in four ongoing pivotal studies:
TOURMALINE-MM1, investigating ixazomib vs. placebo in combination with lenalidomide and dexamethasone in relapsed and/or refractory MM;
TOURMALINE-AL1, investigating ixazomib plus dexamethasone in patients with relapsed or refractory AL amyloidosis;
TOURMALINE-MM2, investigating ixazomib vs. placebo in combination with lenalidomide and dexamethasone in patients with newly diagnosed MM;
TOURMALINE-MM3, investigating ixazomib vs. placebo as maintenance therapy in patients with newly diagnosed MM following induction therapy and autologous stem cell transplant
Source: Takeda News Release

item.title: re: Ferring Reinforces Committment in the Gastro Field
item.description: re: Ferring Reinforces Committment in the Gastro Field
item.content:encoded:
re: Ferring Reinforces Committment in the Gastro Field
GastroEnterology2148 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 08 December 2014 | 11:05

Ferring Reinforces Committment in the Gastro Field [:Endocrinology:comp:Ferring, :GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :GastroEnterology:news]
Comment: TxCell SA, a French biotech developing innovative, personalized cell-based immunotherapies using antigen-specific regulatory T-cells (Ag-Tregs) for chronic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, has granted Ferring an option to acquire an exclusive WW license for the development, manufacture and marketing of Ovasave® (Ph2 planned H2:14) for IBD, including Crohn's Disease(CD) and Ulcerative Colitis (UC).  ...
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / GastroEnterology1943 / 18 March 2014 / 11:21:51 o'clock CET
TxCell SA just announced the enrollment and dosing of the first patient in the Ph2b clinical study. Ovasave® (ovalbumin-specific autologous Treg cells) is currently approved for study in 6 EU countries, with preliminary results expected by the end of 2016 to early 2017. Previously completed studies on Ovasave® demonstrated a favorable tolerance profile and treatment response in 75% of patients, with 38% achieving remission after 5 weeks of treatment.
About Ph2b study
Lead investigator: Dr. Severine Vermeire, Professor of Gastroenterology at the University Hospital Leuven
Reference: CATS29
Location: 32 study sites across Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom
Recruitment: approx. 160 patients with severe refractory Crohn’s disease.
Design: multicentre, randomised, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, multi-dose and multi-injection, 4 parallel groups study.
Objectives: to evaluate the efficacy and the safety of Ovasave (ovalbumin-specific autologous Treg cells (Ova-Treg)) in patients with active refractory Crohn’s disease. CATS29 will be evaluating treatment response rate for one intravenous dose of 1.10(6) cells of Ovasave, compared to a placebo 6 weeks following treatment. Response rate will be measured according to a decrease of at least 100 points in the Crohn’s Disease Activity Index (CDAI).
Dosing/Regimen: Patients will receive, double-blinded, two intravenous (iv) injections 8 weeks apart of either 1.10(4), 1.10(6), or 1.10(7) cells of Ovasave or placebo. Patients will then receive either an open-label treatment with 2 additional iv injections of 1.10(6) cells of Ovasave or a safety follow-up with no injection.
Finally, there will be an extended safety follow-up for all patients.
Source: TxCell PR
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / GastroEnterology2148 / 08 December 2014 / 11:05:35 o'clock CET

item.title: re: Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS
item.description: re: Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS
item.content:encoded:
re: Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS
Oncology10152 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 08 December 2014 | 10:57

Euroscreen's ESN364 to Enter Clinical for Endometriosis and PCOS [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBS, :GastroEnterology:news, :Oncology:dis:Gynea, :PharmaWorld:sub:Partnership]
Comment: The Belgium based, private company presented at ENDO2013 preclinical PK and efficacy data of its oral small-molecule NK3 receptor antagonist program. ESN364, the lead candidate issued from this program, is scheduled for FIM in 4Q:13 (endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome). Of note, the company is actively seeking partner for ESN282 (inflammatory diseases such as ulcerative colitis).  ...
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Oncology9023 / 19 June 2013 / 11:09:30 o'clock CEST
Following "fully-consistent Ph1 results", the company now plans to start 2 Ph2 trials (3-month dosing, 72 patients) for uterine fibroids and Poly Cystic Ovarian Syndrome in January 2015. Company claims the results obtained give a strong competitive advantage compared to GnRH ligand products to provide a superior product with regard to both safety and efficacy for a large scope of indications such as UF, PCOS and Endometriosis in the treatment of Women’s Health.
Study Results
The Ph1 trial enrolled 64 healthy subjects (40 male and 24 female).
Safety was evaluated by means of intensive ECG and vital signs monitoring as well as via the necessary clinical laboratory assessments throughout the entire study (up to 21 days of daily dosing and up to 84 days of follow-up in female volunteers).
No clinically relevant changes were observed in the clinical lab parameters, ECG and/or vital signs. The reported adverse events were mild-to-moderate in intensity, reversible and of limited duration and non-significant in relation to ESN364 treatment based upon comparison to the placebo group.
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Oncology10152 / 08 December 2014 / 10:57:18 o'clock CET

item.title: Daewoong Announces The Completion Of A PhIII Spasticity Study [headline, dis:Spasticity]
item.description: Daewoong Announces The Completion Of A PhIII Spasticity Study [headline, dis:Spasticity]
item.content:encoded:
Daewoong Announces The Completion Of A PhIII Spasticity Study [:Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :Neurology:headline]
Neurology7845 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 05 December 2014 | 16:12

Comment: Daewoong has announced the succesful completion of a phIII clinical study evaluating the safety and efficacy of its botulinum toxin Nabota for "the treatment of stiffness in upper extremity muscles associated with stroke". No actual results have been disclosed. Comments expressed by the company note its strategic intent to enter the therapeutic as well as the aesthetic market on a global scale. However, the nature of the phIII study NCT01945684 conducted in patients is likely to prove insufficient for regulatory purposes in Western markets
PhIII Study Title
A Randomized, Double Blind, Multi-center, Active Drug Controlled, Phase III Clinical Trial to Compare the Safety and Efficacy of DWP450 Versus Botox® in Treatment of Post Stroke Upper Limb(wrist, finger, elbow, thumb)Spasticity
The trial started in 2013 and has as its primary endpoints
  • The change in MAS grade for Wrist flexor [ Time Frame: at 4 week ]
  • The change in MAS grade from baseline at week 4 for wrist flexor muscle tone
Daewoong's press release states the following:-
Jeon Seung-ho, Director of Global Marketing at Daewoong Pharmaceuticals expressed high expectations , saying "The license is expected to be issued in late 2015. One out of three patients with post-stroke stiffness in muscles can be treated using botulinum toxin. Having successfully completed clinical trials, Nabota will gain indications and wide acceptance in the global botulinum toxin treatment market work KRW1.4 trillion, as well as the domestic market for stroke treatment.

item.title: Microbiota Suspension Drug Has Entered Ph2b Trial for Recurrent CDI Infection [news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Microbiota Suspension Drug Has Entered Ph2b Trial for Recurrent CDI Infection [news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Microbiota Suspension Drug Has Entered Ph2b Trial for Recurrent CDI Infection [:GastroEnterology:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
GastroEnterology2142 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 04 December 2014 | 19:20

Comment: Fecal transplantation is gaining increasing acceptance as an effective method of treating recurrent Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). However, there are many unknowns about the therapy including questions about administration. Administration via colonoscopy, nasogastric or nasoduodenal tube, and enema have been reported in the literature. Definitive superiority has not been established for any one method. Rebiotix is developing RBX2660, a new category of biologic drugs that use live human-derived organisms to treat disease.
About RBX2660
Clinical Evidence: Poster link http://www.rebiotix.com/index.php/background-for-microbiota-restoration-therapy/clinical-evidence-rbx2660
RBX2660 consists of live human-derived microbes, is a next generation version of fecal transplantation.
Trial Details
ID NCT02299570 - PUNCH CD 2
Location 20 sites in the US and Canada
PE: Efficacy of Active Treatment Compared to Placebo at Measured at 8 weeks Post-treatment
n=117
  • ≥ 18 years
  • Medical record documentation of recurrent CDI either: a) at least two recurrences after a primary episode and has completed at least two rounds of standard-of-care oral antibiotic therapy or b) has had at least two episodes of severe CDI resulting in hospitalization.
  • Documented history that the subject's recurrent CDI is controlled while on antibiotics even if the subject is not currently on antibiotics.
  • A positive stool test for the presence of C. difficile within 30 days prior to enrollment.
Completion dates June 2015 / June 2017
About Rebiotix
- Founded in 2011
- Aim: to "revolutionize" the treatment of challenging gastrointestinal diseases by harnessing the power of the human microbiome.
The company is developing an entirely new kind of biological drug designed to reverse pathogenic processes responsible for disease through the transplantation of live human-derived microbes into a sick person’s intestinal tract.
Source: clinicaltrials.gov; Rebiotix

Comments
Rebiotix has announced the completion for enrollment of the Ph2b. A total of 117 patients recruited at more than 20 sites in the U.S. and Canada were enrolled in the study, which is the largest randomized controlled study of a Microbiota Restoration Therapy (MRT) for recurrent C. diff. to date.
New Timelines
As a consequence of the delay in the recruitment, new timelines have been postponed to three months.
Estimated Study Completion Date: October 2017
Estimated Primary Completion Date: October 2015 (Final data collection date for primary outcome measure)
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / GastroEnterology2665 / 18 November 2015 / 16:07:33 o'clock CET

item.title: Controversy Builds Over The Applicability of the 2-point Improvement In The Composite Endpoint For GL Which Revance May Use To Its Advantage
item.description: Controversy Builds Over The Applicability of the 2-point Improvement In The Composite Endpoint For GL Which Revance May Use To Its Advantage
item.content:encoded:
Controversy Builds Over The Applicability of the 2-point Improvement In The Composite Endpoint For GL Which Revance May Use To Its Advantage
Neurology7844 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 04 December 2014 | 17:00

Comment: A very interesting report has been issued by BMO Capital Markets post accompanying Revance on an investor tour in Boston & New York. Subsequently there was also an equally informative interactive discussion yesterday at the Piper Jaffray H/C Conference. During both events Dan Brown CEO discussed the recent timeline setback and path forward for the company's topical and injectable toxins. He recognises that there may still be some CMC issues to address, similar issues having been incurred by Allergan and J&J. However, based on the response from the ASDSA and others to recent FDA Draft Guidance on Upper Facial Lines, he seems confident that the company can find a way forward for RT-001 in lateral canthal lines. Moreover, he continues to emphasise how development plans for RT-001 in HH and RT-002 remain unaffected by any ongoing issues with RT-001.
Below are some of the key feedback points from both events regarding key questions:-

Why do you think the product didn’t perform as well as it did in Phase II?

Revance explained that botulinum is a very complex molecule and while results proved to be statistically significant on the 1-point scale, the data for the composite endpoint was not in the 35-45% range of signal the company had outlined in its S-1. Given that the Phase IIb trial serves as a last chance to make changes before initiating a Phase III, Revance felt that it wanted to work to see data within that 35-45% range of signal and want to have the greatest probability of success before starting Phase III. Allergan Johnson & Johnson and Merz Pharmaceuticals had issues at some point during the CMC process.

According to Revance, Allergan, who also used List Biological Laboratories, Inc for its initial batches, experienced problems during the CMC process, faced stability issues and almost ran out of product. JNJ experienced setbacks in the CMC process as well, which Revance believes likely happened later in the development stage, but notes that it is hard to tell from available information. Also, further speaking to the complexity of the molecule, Allergan at one point had tried to increase dose to get a longer duration, and adverse events rose significantly.

What was the nature of the results seen in the recent open-label trial with the initial batch from the new plant and wat is the latest on the FDA Draft Guidance & Its Implications For Revance?

The initial batch was shown to be statistically significant; the variance, however, is in the endpoints. The regulatory endpoint is a 2-point improvement, whereas the clinical endpoint is a 1-point improvement. According to the company, it and doctors working with RT001, Botox and other Botox-like products feel that the 2-point scale is not the result or look patients are seeking.

What Revance is finding is that patients want to avoid the “frozen look” and are opting for a result more along the lines of a 1-point improvement. As a result, many doctors are using smaller dosing to achieve this optimal look along the lines of a 1-point improvement. At the commercial scale, the 2-point improvement was a little less than the results seen in the Phase II trial.

Yesterday Dan Brown further endorsed this point about the composite endpoint having no influence on the way clinicians are using botulinum toxins. He was citing the ASDSA letter (see attached) that has been sent to the FDA following the issuance of its draft guidance and suggested that in essence the regulatory authorities are playing catch up with clinical practice.
The extract from the ASDSA letter he refers to is as shown below:- Other Considerations Our members have expressed concern that the "FDA 2 point improvement" standard could be perceived as:
1) A potential overtreatment, especially as patients now desire a more "natural " result. Complete lack of facial movement is potentially seen as an adverse event - not an aesthetic benefit, particularly in the face. (In a spastic limb it might be somewhat acceptable.) In addition, many of the positive results of BTX-A are not related to just muscle weakness and may include reduction in erythema, pigmentation, and increases in skin luminosity due to the effects on neocollagenesis. Reduction in erythema, in pigmentation, increases in skin luminosity due to the effects on neocollagenesis.
2) Not related to the current practice environment and patient expectations.
3) Unrelated to the previous research standards, requiring the use of a "1 point improvement" this could hinder future research.

According to Revance, there have been three responses to the FDA’s draft guidance. The likely next steps would be for the FDA to incorporate feedback and revise the draft in the coming years. Revance believes that it does not make sense to wait for final draft guidance, as the timing is not clear and points out that the guidance does not impact its injectab le product. To shed further light on the impact of the draft guidance, management provides several examples where draft guidance has remained in draft form for an extended period of time and to this date has not be resolved into final guidance. The company feels confident that it will be able to get its topical product approved given its previous interactions with the FDA and the fact that the draft guidance does not explicitly say that the company’s endpoints are insufficient to receive approval.

If anybody would like to see a full copy of the report please contact Jacquelyne Cantle

Source BMO Report November 26th & Pipar Jaffray H/C Conference 3rd December

- charged with rapid identification, development, and regulatory approval of products within the clinical therapeutic areas of Reproductive Health, Orthopedics, Gastroenterology and Urology.

item.description: re: Astellas Terminates ASP015K License Agreement with Janssen and Reports EU Approval of XTANDI
item.content:encoded:
re: Astellas Terminates ASP015K License Agreement with Janssen and Reports EU Approval of XTANDI
Oncology10149 | Posted by frv17817 | 03 December 2014 | 16:46

Astellas Terminates ASP015K License Agreement with Janssen and Reports EU Approval of XTANDI [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Comment: Astellas has ended its October 2012 licensing agreement with Janssen regarding the WW development and commercialisation of ASP015K (currently in Ph3 for moderate-to-severe RA). In parallel, the company has announced the European approval of XTANDI in the chemo-naïve setting. Management expects a launch in the first EU countries, including the UK, from December 2014.  ...
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Oncology10145 / 02 December 2014 / 14:44:13 o'clock CET
just adding some info on the study (which you may have elsewhere on Traction). Based on PREVAIL, it is after failure of ADT. I wonder if there is info on how this is to be documented in real-life and what is considered failure: PSA progression or side effects. In case of the latter, it opens the door for 'covert' first line treatment. Do you know if the updated EPAR is already available that might elucidate this? http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/medicines/human/medicines/002639/smops/Positive/human_smop_000742.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac058001d127
The European Commission has amended the marketing authorisation for Xtandi (enzalutamide) to include first-line treatment for men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) after failure of androgen deprivation therapy. It was originally approved in Europe in June 2013 for mCRPC patients whose disease has progressed on or after docetaxel.

The latest green light is based on the Phase III PREVAIL study which demonstrated that compared with placebo, Xtandi reduced the risk of death by 29% and the risk of radiographic progression or death by 81%. Men treated with the oral, once-daily androgen receptor signalling inhibitor experienced a 17-month delay in the time to initiation of chemo compared to placebo (28.0 months versus 10.8 months).
Bertrand Tombal of the Université Catholique de Louvain and European principal investigator for PREVAIL, said Xtandi “provides a viable treatment option for a broad population of men with mCRPC, regardless of age, or their readiness for chemotherapy”. He added that the decision from the European Commission “is a very important milestone”.

Astellas expects to launch Xtandi in the chemotherapy-naïve setting in the first European countries, including the UK, this month. Astellas partner Medivation got US approval for the pre-chemo indication in September.


Read more at: http://www.pharmatimes.com/Article/14-12-02/EU_okays_Astellas_Xtandi_for_pre-chemo_prostate_cancer.aspx#ixzz3KqjVL5OC

Sanofi in Talks toTransfer its Toulouse R&D Site to Evotec [:Oncology:comp:SanofiAventis]
PharmaWorld11023 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 December 2014 | 12:15

Comment: Under the agreed deal, to be signed in 1H 2015, Sanofi has reported it would transfer its on-site research and development jobs and activities to Evotec, and invest $310M to develop joint research-programs, notably in oncology. France accounts for just 8% of Sanofi's revenue but close to half of its research staff.
About the Agreement
Sanofi would transfer 209 of the 250 people it employs in Toulouse to Evotec, and would invest €250 million ($309.59 million) to develop joint-research programs, notably in oncology.
Evotec will commit to maintaining the site’s work force levels until 2019.

item.title: Myraid's Prolaris® Could Have An Impact On Healthcare Saving Of $6 Billion Over 10 Years [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Myraid's Prolaris® Could Have An Impact On Healthcare Saving Of $6 Billion Over 10 Years [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Myraid's Prolaris® Could Have An Impact On Healthcare Saving Of $6 Billion Over 10 Years [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10148 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 03 December 2014 | 12:12

Comment: Three studies with Prolaris® in prostate cancer pateints will be highlighted at the 2014 Society of Urologic Oncology (SUO) Annual Meeting. The additional data presented from three stdueis validates active surveillance threshold using Prolaris Score - implicates a potential saving of $6 billion over 10 years if the physicians are using the Prolaris test appropriately to personalize treatemtn options for their prostate cancer.
2014 SUO - POSTER PRESENTATIONS
   
Title: Evaluation of the Economic Impact of the CCP Assay in Localized Prostate
  Cancer.
Presenter: E. David Crawford
Date: Wednesday, Dec. 3, 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET
Summary In a study that evaluated the economic impact of the Prolaris test, researchers found the test reduced costs by $2,850 per patient tested, which over a 10-year period could save the healthcare system $6 billion. For a health plan of approximately 30 million members, this would translate into more than $48 million in savings. It is estimated that two-thirds of these savings would be achieved in the first year after testing. The cost savings were driven by more use of active surveillance in low- and intermediate-risk patients and from lower disease progression rates in high-risk patients who received more extensive treatment.
Title: Impact of CCP Test on Personalizing Treatment Decisions: Results from a Large
  Prospective Registry of Newly Diagnosed Prostate Cancer Patients.
Presenter: Mark Gonzalgo
Date: Wednesday, Dec. 3, 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET
Summary These are the interim results from PROCEDE 1000, which is the largest prospective clinical utility study to date that evaluates the impact of the Prolaris test on personalizing prostate cancer treatment. The interim data analysis of 816 patients demonstrated that physicians changed their treatment decisions in 44 percent of cases based on results from the Prolaris test. In 32 percent of patients, the Prolaris test score led to a reduction in treatment, while 12 percent of patients received more aggressive treatment based on their test score.
Title: Validation of an Active Surveillance Threshold for the CCP Score in
  Conservatively Managed Men with Localized Prostate Cancer.
Presenter: Steven Stone
Date: Wednesday, Dec. 3, 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET
Summary The results showed that there were no observed cancer deaths in patients who fell below the defined threshold. In a separate analysis of 1,718 patients from a commercial cohort, approximately 55 percent of the patients qualified for active surveillance based on the threshold.
Source: News Release Myriad.com 2 December 2014

item.title: Servier Inks Development & Commercialisation Agreement With GeNeuro In Multiple Sclerosis Valued at $455m [news]
item.description: Servier Inks Development & Commercialisation Agreement With GeNeuro In Multiple Sclerosis Valued at $455m [news]
item.content:encoded:
Servier Inks Development & Commercialisation Agreement With GeNeuro In Multiple Sclerosis Valued at $455m [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7841 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 December 2014 | 18:54

Comment: GeNeuro SA, a biopharmaceutical company focusing on new therapies for neurology and autoimmune disorders, announced today that it has entered into a strategic partnership with Servier to develop and market GNbAC1 in MS. The drug is seen as having the potential to target a causal factor of the disease and therefore to radically change the way MS patients are treated.
What is GNbAC1 Targeting?
GNbAC1, a humanized monoclonal antibody, targets MSRV-Env, the envelope protein of MS associated retrovirus, a member of the HERV-W family, the expression of which is usually silent but reactivated and expressed in MS lesions from an early stage in the disease. This protein has been shown to be both pro-inflammatory and an inhibitor of remyelination, the two major drivers of MS pathophysiology.
By targeting MSRV-Env, GeNeuro expects to bring to patients a safe, effective treatment that can halt progression of both relapsing-remitting and progressive forms of the disease without hampering the patient’s immune system. GNbAC1 has successfully completed Phase IIa, demonstrating an optimal safety profile and encouraging signs of efficacy on a first small cohort of patients.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, GeNeuro will be responsible for the development of GNbAC1 until completion of Phase IIb, after which Servier can exercise the option to license the product for all markets excluding the USA and Japan.
Financial considerations
These include an upfront payment by Servier to GeNeuro of US$47 million to finance the completion of Phase IIb.
Subsequent to exercising the option agreement, Servier will cover the costs of the Phase III global development program and pay GeNeuro up to US$408 million in future development and sales milestones, as well as royalties on future sales.
Servier will also have the option to take an equity stake in GeNeuro as a minority shareholder in the next 12 months.
Source: www.servier.com

item.title: Otsuka Plans To Buy Avanir For $3.5bn [news]
item.description: Otsuka Plans To Buy Avanir For $3.5bn [news]
item.content:encoded:
Otsuka Plans To Buy Avanir For $3.5bn [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7840 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 December 2014 | 18:44

Comment: Japanese drug maker Otsuka plans to buy US based Avanir to expand its neurologic/degenerative disease drug portfolio ahead of the expiration of a key drug patent for its schizophrnia drug Abilify which represents 40% of group sales. The extraordinarily high price it is prepared to pay (35x estimated 2014 sales) inidicates the appetite that is still out there for perceived growth opportunities, particularly one might argue amongst the Japanese who are cash rich and looking for international expansion opportunities.
Deal Terms
Otsuka will pay $17 per share in cash, a 13.3% premium to Avanir's closing price on Monday. Otsuka will launch a tender offer within 10 business days to purchase all outstanding shares of Avanir, financied from existing cash. The transaction is expected to cloase in the first quarter of 2015.
It is planned that Avanir will operate as a unit of Otsuka America Inc and will partner with the group to enhance its development and marketing efforts in central nervous system-related disorders.
Avanir Profile
Source: otsuka.com

item.title: Insight on Revance's RT002 Ph2 Comparator Study for Moderate/Severe GL [sub:Aesthetics, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Canada]
item.description: Insight on Revance's RT002 Ph2 Comparator Study for Moderate/Severe GL [sub:Aesthetics, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Canada]
item.content:encoded:
Insight on Revance's RT002 Ph2 Comparator Study for Moderate/Severe GL [:Neurology:sub:Aesthetics, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Canada, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Neurology7838 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 December 2014 | 16:42

Comment: RT002 is manufactured in house and has not been associated with the same issues as RT001. The aim of the 5-arm study is to assess safety/efficacy of the drug in approx. 250 participants. PE will measure proportion of subjects assessed as responders by investigator assessment of severity of glabellar lines at maximum frown, and duration of response assessed by investigator assessment of severity of glabellar lines at maximum frown from the date of injection to when subject reverts to baseline severity. Interim results are likely to be reported in 2H:2015.
Upcoming Milestone
1Q2015- Select RT002 therapeutic indication
Trial ID NCT02303002
Design The five-arm, doser anging study has three active arms, a placebo arm and a Botox arm.
Timelines Start date Dec 2014 Completion dates Dec 2015 / March 2016
Inclusion Criteria
  • Moderate or severe glabellar frown lines
  • Female or male, 30 to 65 years of age in good general health
  • Women of childbearing potential must agree to use an effective method of birth control during the course of the study
  • Willing to refrain from receipt of facial fillers, laser treatments or use of products that affect skin remodeling and causes an active dermal response
Location Canada

item.title: FDA Lifts Clinical Hold On Flexion's New Osteoarthritis Drug [news]
item.description: FDA Lifts Clinical Hold On Flexion's New Osteoarthritis Drug [news]
item.content:encoded:
FDA Lifts Clinical Hold On Flexion's New Osteoarthritis Drug [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7837 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 December 2014 | 15:35

Comment: Flexion can now resume its phIIb trial which was halted in September after one patient developed a knee infection. It has since been determined that FX006 did not cause the infection. Alongside its announcement Felxion has also announced plans to initiate a late-stage study by early next year.
FX006 is a first-in-class injectable, sustained-release, intra-articular steroid treatment in development for patients with moderate to severe osteoarthritis (OA).
The Sequence Of Events
On September 16, 2014, the FDA placed a clinical hold on FX006 due to a single occurrence of what was then described as an infection in the injected knee joint of a patient in the pivotal Phase 2b trial. The subsequent clinical hold letter from the FDA requested that the company:
  • Determine whether the study drug was the source of infection by recovering both the specific study drug vials used in the treatment of the patient who experienced the infection, as well as unused study drug vials from the clinical site where the patient was injected and test them for contamination, and
  • Explore other potential causes for infection, including a compromise of sterile procedures during injection.
In accordance with these FDA requests, the company performed industry standard contamination tests through a certified third-party sterility-testing firm, which demonstrated that no microbial growth could be detected in any of the used or unused vials. As a result, the company concluded that study drug was not contaminated.
The company also explored other potential causes of possible infection including contamination during the preparation or administration of FX006. Following consultations with the principal investigator, the study coordinator that prepared the study drug, and the healthcare professional that administered the injection at the clinical site, the company could not find any indication that sterile procedures were compromised during the injection. There have been no other infections noted in the approximately 100 other patients dosed with FX006 in this trial.
On October 28, 2014, the company received notification that based on the highly atypical nature of this patient's presentation as it relates to septic arthritis and the subsequent clinical course, which was most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis, the principal investigator has changed the initial serious adverse event diagnosis from septic arthritis, possibly related to study drug treatment, to inflammatory arthritis, unrelated to study drug treatment.
Thus there have been no confirmed diagnoses of septic arthritis among the more than 300 patients treated with FX006 in all clinical trials to date and no serious adverse events that have been attributed to study drug.
Flexion Pipeline Profile
The company also has two additional product candidates, FX007, a locally administered TrkA receptor antagonist for post-operative pain, and FX005, an intra-articular, sustained-release p38 MAP kinase inhibitor for end-stage OA patients.
Source: www.flexiontherapeutics.com

Astellas Terminates ASP015K License Agreement with Janssen and Reports EU Approval of XTANDI [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10145 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 December 2014 | 14:44

Comment: Astellas has ended its October 2012 licensing agreement with Janssen regarding the WW development and commercialisation of ASP015K (currently in Ph3 for moderate-to-severe RA). In parallel, the company has announced the European approval of XTANDI in the chemo-naïve setting. Management expects a launch in the first EU countries, including the UK, from December 2014.
More to Come for XTANDI
XTANDI’s results in a Phase 1/2 trial for a triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) indication are due to be announced at next week’s San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium. This is a tough indication for which there are no existing treatments.
Licensing Agreement Astellas/Janssen Biotech for ASP015K
The deal, valued at $945M ($65M upfront + $880M milestones), was signed in October 2012 for Astellas to maximize the value of its drug (in Ph2b), and Janssen to expand its portfolio in the setting.
Source: Astellas

Bertrand Tombal of the Université Catholique de Louvain and European principal investigator for PREVAIL, said Xtandi “provides a viable treatment option for a broad population of men with mCRPC, regardless of age, or their readiness for chemotherapy”. He added that the decision from the European Commission “is a very important milestone”.
