item.title: VT-464, A CYP17 Lypase Inhibtor, Is Trialled For Ph2 In mCRPC Patients Who are Resistant To Abiraterone Or Enzalutamide [dis:Prostate]
item.description: VT-464, A CYP17 Lypase Inhibtor, Is Trialled For Ph2 In mCRPC Patients Who are Resistant To Abiraterone Or Enzalutamide [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
VT-464, A CYP17 Lypase Inhibtor, Is Trialled For Ph2 In mCRPC Patients Who are Resistant To Abiraterone Or Enzalutamide [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10103 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 14 November 2014 | 12:19

Comment: Innocrin Pharmaceuticals (a privately held company) and the Prostate Cancer Foundation (PCF) collaborate to initiate a multi-centre Ph2 study of VT-464 in mCRPC patients who are resistant to abiraterone or enzalutamide. PCF is to provide $1 million for this biomarker based study. This will be the second trial to explore this patient setting. The first trial is being done by Tokai with its Galeterone, of which was highlighted during the ESMO this year in relation to AR-V7. AR-V7 has been discussed frequently as early data suggested the link between AR-V7 and treatment outcome with abiraterone and enzalutamide.
Dr Howard Scher (Chief of GU Oncology Service at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center) is the PI of the study that is slated to begin in 1H 2015. Interestingly, Dr Mary-Ellen Taplin is also one of the co-investigators on this study. Dr Taplin is the PI on TOKAI's ARMOR-2 Study (Galeterone) and presenting the interim Ph2 data of the trial at the EORTC-NCI-AACR Symposium on 18-21 November in Barcelona, Spain. The presentation entitled " Activity of galeterone in CRPC with C-terminal AR loss: Results from ARMOR2" will be highlighted as an oral presentation during the Plenary Session 2 on Wednesday on 19th Nov at 2.05 pm (CET).
Innocrin's ongoing CRPC clinical trials include
  • Ph1/2 Open label PK, Safety, Tolerability and Efficacy Study: Phase 1/2 open-label study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy of VT-464 in CRPC patients who are treatment-naïve or whose disease has progressed following treatment with either abiraterone, enzalutamide or both (NCT02012920)
  • Ph2 Open label (NCI funded): A Phase 2 open-label study, that is being funded by the National Cancer Institute, to evaluate the efficacy and safety of VT-464 in patients with metastatic CRPC who have previously been treated with enzalutamide (NCT02130700)
Innocrin’s investors include Novartis Venture Fund, Lilly Ventures, Hatteras Venture Partners, Intersouth Partners, Lurie Holdings, and Astellas Venture Management.
Source: www.innocrinpharma.com; business wire

item.title: Real World Observational Study of Pfizer's Sunitinib in Chinese Patients with pNET [comp:Pfizer, dis:pNET, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
item.description: Real World Observational Study of Pfizer's Sunitinib in Chinese Patients with pNET [comp:Pfizer, dis:pNET, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
item.content:encoded:
Real World Observational Study of Pfizer's Sunitinib in Chinese Patients with pNET [:Endocrinology:comp:Pfizer, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
Endocrinology7861 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 13 November 2014 | 17:09

Comment: The purpose of this non-interventional (NI) study is to assess the safety and efficacy of sunitinib in Chinese patients with progressive, unresectable, advanced or metastatic well-differentiated, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors(pNET). Approx. 100 adults will be recruited in China hospitals.
Study Details
Reference: NCT02282059
Timelines: Ph4 expected to start next month and complete Nov 2022
Intervention: subjects will be enrolled to receive at least one dose of sunitinib orally at 37.5 mg once a day on a continuous daily dosing regimen (CDD) or dosage modification is based on daily clinic practice.

Inclusion Criteria

  • Evidence of a personally signed and dated informed consent document indicating that the subject (or a legally acceptable representative) has been informed of all pertinent aspects of the study.
  • Subjects who are willing to follow up visits within current clinical practice.
  • Histologically or cytologically proven diagnosis of well-differentiated pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (according to WHO 2000 classification)
  • Unresectable (as assessed by the investigator) or metastatic disease documented on a scan
  • A minimum age of 18 years

item.title: Revance Reports Further Delay for RT001 During its Q3 Earnings Call [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Hyperhydrosis, sub:Aesthetics]
item.description: Revance Reports Further Delay for RT001 During its Q3 Earnings Call [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Hyperhydrosis, sub:Aesthetics]
item.content:encoded:
Revance Reports Further Delay for RT001 During its Q3 Earnings Call [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:dis:Hyperhydrosis, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7812 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 13 November 2014 | 16:13

Comment: Alongside its Q3 financial results, Revance reported that the development timeline for RT001 has been further delayed due to inadequate preliminary results from the company’s ongoing open-label study to confirm successful transfer of production of RT001 drug product to its U.S. commercial manufacturing facility. However management emphasized its development programs for RT001 for hyperhidrosis and RT002 for glabellar (frown) lines remain on track, and are unaffected by the delay to RT001 for crow’s feet lines.
RT001 - Hyperhidrosis
Timelines - planning to initiate Ph2 study in early 2015
Revance will be using the same RT001 product it is currently using in the ongoing RT001 for CFL trial for its hyperhidrosis Ph2 study, and made sure to point out the difference in anatomy and end points in these indications.
RT002 - Glabellar (Frown) Lines
Timelines - Revance expects to begin a Ph2 active comparator trial before the end of the year.
Design: The five-arm, dose-ranging study will have three active arms, a placebo arm and a Botox Cosmetic arm, and will include approx 250 subjects. Revance expects interim results in late 2015.
2015 Milestone Events
2014 FINANCIAL OUTLOOK
Revance completed the company’s initial public offering (IPO) in February 2014, resulting in net proceeds of $98.7 million and had a follow-on offering in June 2014 resulting in net proceeds of $131.3 million.
As of November 12, 2014, Revance anticipates 2014 operating expenses excluding amortization, depreciation and stock-based compensation will be in the range of $45 to 50 million.
The Company expects its 2014 cash burn to be in the range of $65 million to $75 million.

item.title: re: EU Registration Trials for Norgine's Novel Low Volume Bowel Preparation
item.description: re: EU Registration Trials for Norgine's Novel Low Volume Bowel Preparation
item.content:encoded:
re: EU Registration Trials for Norgine's Novel Low Volume Bowel Preparation
GastroEnterology2119 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 13 November 2014 | 15:37

EU Registration Trials for Norgine's Novel Low Volume Bowel Preparation [:GastroEnterology:news, :GastroEnterology:sub:CRCPrevention, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Europe, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Comment: Newly listed in clinicaltrials.gov. the 2 studies, expected to recruit approx 1,300 participants, have been part of the EU registration trials for Norgine's NER1006. The DAYB study will compare NER1006 vs CITRAFLEET using a day befre only dosing regimen in adults. The MORA study will compare NER1006 vs MOVIPREP using a 2-day split-dosing regimen and a 1-day morning slit-dosing regimen in adults. Both studies have similar timelines, and efficacy as primary endpoint.  ...
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / GastroEnterology2105 / 30 October 2014 / 18:00:51 o'clock CET
Norgine announced today the enrolment of the first patients into the two EU Ph3 studies (MORA and DAYB), as well as the countries involved in each trial (listed below).
The following EU countries will be included in the MORA and DAYB clinical trials:
  • MORA: Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Spain and UK
  • DAYB: Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Spain and UK
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / GastroEnterology2119 / 13 November 2014 / 15:37:55 o'clock CET

item.title: All Four Divisions of the Merck Group Posted Organic Sales Growth in Q3:14 [class:GrowthHormone, prod:Saizen, :GastroEnterology:sub:Probiotics, :GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea]
item.description: All Four Divisions of the Merck Group Posted Organic Sales Growth in Q3:14 [class:GrowthHormone, prod:Saizen, :GastroEnterology:sub:Probiotics, :GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea]
item.content:encoded:
All Four Divisions of the Merck Group Posted Organic Sales Growth in Q3:14 [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone, :Endocrinology:prod:Saizen, :GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea, :GastroEnterology:sub:Probiotics]
Endocrinology7860 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 13 November 2014 | 14:17

Comment: The Merck Serono division generated organic sales growth of 4.5%. Sales of Saizen®, the top-selling product of the endocrinology franchise, saw an organic increase of 0.5% as well as negative exchange rate effects of –1.8%. Consequently, sales almost reached the previous year’s level of € 60 million. More details on growth drivers and strategy are provided below. Of note, as of January 1, 2014, two product groups were transferred from the Merck Serono division to the Consumer Health division. These are Neurobion®, a vitamin B-based analgesic, and Floratil®, a leading brand in the probiotic antidiarrheal segment in Brazil. Sales of the two products totaled € 265 million in 2013.
Organic Growth by Product
  • Rebif®, top-selling product, is used to treat relapsing forms of MS, which is one of the most common neurological diseases among young adults.
  • Erbitux® for the targeted and personalized treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer is the second best-selling drug in Merck Serono’s product portfolio.
Growth Across All Regions
Emerging markets drive organic growth.

item.title: Xofigo Production Is Resumed And Expected To Supply For New Patients On 17th Nov [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Xofigo Production Is Resumed And Expected To Supply For New Patients On 17th Nov [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Xofigo Production Is Resumed And Expected To Supply For New Patients On 17th Nov [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10100 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 13 November 2014 | 10:53

Comment: Following the manufacture issue for Xofigo and continuous uncertainty of timeline for Bayer to resume supply, Bayer has announced that the production of Xofigo has now been resumed. The issue identified was due to small fibrous particles found in some of the vials during the standard inspection process. Bayer has agreed with Health Authorities that now for all the product batch released, filtration is required to be done prior to administration to the patient until further notification.The initial batch of Xofigo has been released and Bayer has made this available for the patients.
Source: http://www.xofigo-us.com/patient, http://www.xofigo.com/hcp/resources,

item.title: GP Pharm's Triptorelin Development Program is on Hold [:DKPHybrids:prod:Leuprorelin, :DKPHybrids:prod:Triptorelin, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.description: GP Pharm's Triptorelin Development Program is on Hold [:DKPHybrids:prod:Leuprorelin, :DKPHybrids:prod:Triptorelin, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.content:encoded:
GP Pharm's Triptorelin Development Program is on Hold [:DKPHybrids:prod:Leuprorelin, :DKPHybrids:prod:Triptorelin, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:headline]
Oncology10099 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 13 November 2014 | 09:21

Comment: Feedback from the CPhI congress (October 2014, Paris) has highlighted that triptorelin 1M has been launched in Peru. Additionally, recent external intelligence has outlined that GP Pharm's triptorelin development is on hold, and that the company requires a partner to progress with the product. EU/US timelines for Lutrate 1M & 3M are provided below.
Analysis of Lutrate Timelines
(source: GP Pharm product list; Primary intelligence)
Lutrate 1M
- Approved in 23 countries (France still not included)
  • currently marketed in Spain, will be commercially available Q1:15 in Germany, Portugal and Eastern Europe (countries not confirmed)
- Filled in the US in July 2014, and anticipated to be vailable in Q3:15
- Filled in China/HK in June 2014
Lutrate 3M
- Filled in EU in April 2014,and anticipated to be available by Q2:15 (if we benchmark with the 1M, first country may be Spain)
- Filled in the US in July 2014, and anticipated to have the same timeline as the 1M (Q3:15)
Lutrate 6M
According to the product list, the Ph3 is 'to be started' (timelines unknown)

item.title: Key Messages from Versartis's Long-Acting Growth Hormone Development Plans [class:GrowthHormone, dis:GrowthHormoneDeficiency, news]
item.description: Key Messages from Versartis's Long-Acting Growth Hormone Development Plans [class:GrowthHormone, dis:GrowthHormoneDeficiency, news]
item.content:encoded:
Key Messages from Versartis's Long-Acting Growth Hormone Development Plans [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone, :Endocrinology:dis:GrowthHormoneDeficiency, :Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7856 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 14:59

Comment: Versartis is focused on the execution of VRS-317 pediatric Ph3 study, which is expected to start in the US, Western Europe and Canada in early 2015. Six-month height velocity data and 12-month data may be provided by mid-2016 an early 2017 respectively with a potential FDA approval planned by mid-2018. The company is currently developing an injection device, which will use a 29-gauge needle.
Establishment of a EU HQ
Versartis has plans to grow its global presence by establishing its European headquarters in Switzerland
Semi-monthly Ph3 Study in Ped GHD
Design: The Phase 3 trial will be an open label, randomized controlled study to evaluate the noninferiority of VRS-317 dosed semimonthly compared to daily growth hormone therapy. Versartis have selected semimonthly dosing because it has a commercial formulation ready for the trial to enable the majority of GHD children to receive a single injection from the small gauge needle twice per month.
Dosage: 3.5 milligrams/kg
Location: up to 70 clinical sites in the US, Western Europe and Canada
Japan Ped Ph2/3 Clinical Development
Enrolment expected to begin early 2015
Adult Ph2/3 Program
Management intends to meet with the FDA and obtain scientific advice from EMA in the first half of 2015 on the planned Phase 2/3 design to enable registration of monthly VRS-317 dosing GHD adults, and anticipates enrollment to begin in H2:2015.
Source: Versartis transcript

item.title: Norgine's MOVIPREP® Can Reduce Long-Term Colorectal Cancer Treatment Costs in Germany [sub:CRCPrevention, headline, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Germany]
item.description: Norgine's MOVIPREP® Can Reduce Long-Term Colorectal Cancer Treatment Costs in Germany [sub:CRCPrevention, headline, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Germany]
item.content:encoded:
Norgine's MOVIPREP® Can Reduce Long-Term Colorectal Cancer Treatment Costs in Germany [:GastroEnterology:headline, :GastroEnterology:sub:CRCPrevention, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Germany, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing]
GastroEnterology2116 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 13:41

Comment: Results from the MODEC study, presented at IPSOR in Amsterdam, show that the cleansing quality of MOVIPREP® is greater than NaPic/MgCit for all segments of the colon (98.0% vs. 57.5%, p<0.0001). The long-term cost consequence model also predicts that while the use of MOVIPREP® vs. NaPic/MgCit increases the average per-patient cost associated with colonoscopy by €67, MOVIPREP® enables better bowel cleansing which permits the early detection of polyps and adenomas resulting in less progression to colorectal cancer and an average per-patient saving in colorectal cancer treatment costs of €488. The cost consequence model predicts an average overall cost saving of €420 per patient over a 10 year period.
Presentation @ ISPOR
Data from the study presented at the International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcome Research (ISPOR) 17th Annual European Congress in Amsterdam (Fischbach W, et al. Cost consequence model investigating the impact of bowel cleansing on prevention of colorectal cancer in a German screening population. ISPOR 17th Annual European Congress 2014 abstract ). [:GastroEnterology:PCN97]
About the Study
Reference: Pohl J, et al. A multicentre, randomised, investigator-blinded study (MODEC) comparing the cleansing quality and the observed lesion detection rate of two bowel preparations: 2L Polyethylene Glycol with Electrolytes + Ascorbate Components (:PEG+ASC) and Sodium Picosulfate/Magnesium Citrate (NaPic/MgCit). ACG Annual Scientific Meeting 2014 abstract.
Objective: to evaluate the clinical and economic impact of bowel cleansing quality, using efficacy rates of colorectal cancer screening and subsequent cost of treating colorectal cancer in a cohort of patients undergoing screening colonoscopy in Germany
Recruitment: 394
Protocol: Patients were randomised to receive either 2L MOVIPREP® (PEG+ASC, n=201) or sodium picosulfate/magnesium citrate (NaPic/MgCit, n=193)
Availability of MOVIPREP®
It is available in EU and Australia through Norgine’s own infrastructure, and in Eastern Europe, the US, India, Japan and Canada via partners.
Additionally, The Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation granted approval for MOVIPREP® in Russia on 22 September 2014 (see GastroEnterology2095: MOVIPREP® Approved in Russia).

item.title: AbbVie and Enterome Enter Microbiome-Based Collaboration in Crohn's Disease [headline, dis:IBD, sub:Diagnostic]
item.description: AbbVie and Enterome Enter Microbiome-Based Collaboration in Crohn's Disease [headline, dis:IBD, sub:Diagnostic]
item.content:encoded:
AbbVie and Enterome Enter Microbiome-Based Collaboration in Crohn's Disease [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :GastroEnterology:headline, :GastroEnterology:sub:Diagnostic]
GastroEnterology2114 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 11:54

Comment: The alliance is anchored around Enterome's proprietary metagenomic biomarker portfolio and technologies that may enable the development of novel diagnostic products to support personalized therapies and the development of new drugs in microbiome-related diseases. The companies will first collaborate to develop non-invasive monitoring tools of the gut microbiome in Crohn's disease.
Enterome Snapshot
  • Paris-based private company
  • spun out from the results of the scientific research of Dr Stanislav Dusko Ehrlich (INRA, Paris) and his team on the measurement and modulation of gut microbiota’s role in health and diseases
  • established in 2012 and has already raised a €7.5m series A with three private equity funds (Seventure, Omnes Capital & Lundbeckfond Ventures) and two strategic investors (Danone & Shire).
Technology
The method used by Enterome is based on mapping of total fecal bacterial gene content and functions, leading to the characterization of a personal metagenome (metagenotype®) potentially for each individual.
Each metagenotype® is analyzed using proprietary algorithms (linking individual metagenotype® to associated phenotypes) allowing proper evaluation of personal risk of each subject to develop a wide variety of pathological conditions.
Source: Enterome PR

item.title: Inhibition of SRPK1 Activity Could Stop Prostate Cancer Progression [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Inhibition of SRPK1 Activity Could Stop Prostate Cancer Progression [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Inhibition of SRPK1 Activity Could Stop Prostate Cancer Progression [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10098 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 11:38

Comment: By analysing samples of human prostate cancer, researchers observed that SRPK1 increases as the cancer gets more aggressive. Biotech company Exonate, a spin-out drug development company from the University of Nottingham, aims to develop SRPK1 inhibitors as treatments for age-related macular degeneration (lead program) and cancer (for which a partner is sought).
Study in Mice
This study has been funded by Prostate Cancer UK, the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC) and Richard Bright VEGF Research Trust.
When scientists injected mice three times a week with a drug to stop molcule SRPK1 from working, their tumour growth halted.
Dr Sebastian Oltean, the study's co-author from the U. of Bristol's School of Physiology and Pharmacology shows in his paper that if "we decrease SRPK1 levels in prostate cancer cells we are able to inhibit tumour vasculature and growth".
Exonate Snapshot
Incorporated in December 2013.
Technology
http://exonate.com/technology/
Investors
Exonate closed seed round £400,00 in March 2014.
Team
  • Dr Catherine Beech (CEO)
  • Prof David Bates (CSO) Prof of Oncology and Head of Cancer Biology, Div of Oncology atht he U of Nottingham.
Source: Exonate PR

item.title: Daewoong Builds Research Institute in China [:PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
item.description: Daewoong Builds Research Institute in China [:PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
item.content:encoded:
Daewoong Builds Research Institute in China [:PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
Neurology7811 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 10:52

Comment: 'Daewoong China Research Institute' is the corporate research institute inside Liaoning Baifeng, the Chinese pharma company acquired in August 2013. The company now has offices in Beijing, and factories and labs in Shenyang. With these establishments, it plans to reach sales revenue of about $463.4M within China by 2020.
Rationale & Strategy
Daewoong China Research Institute plans to recruit about 10 researchers.
The lab develops oral solution products, and solid formulations for Chinese consumers.
- collaboration with major institutions in the three Northeast Provinces in China, such as local colleges of pharmacy, research centers and other pharma companies in drug technologies and research.
According to head researcher of the company, the strategy is expected to help Daewoong expand in not only markets in China and Korea but also elsewhere in the world.
Source: Daewoong PR

item.title: GTx Provides Corporate Updates for Capesaris® and Ostarine® [dis:Prostate, class:Antihormonals]
item.description: GTx Provides Corporate Updates for Capesaris® and Ostarine® [dis:Prostate, class:Antihormonals]
item.content:encoded:
GTx Provides Corporate Updates for Capesaris® and Ostarine® [:Oncology:class:Antihormonals, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10096 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 12 November 2014 | 10:06

Comment: Alongside its financial results for the third quarter and nine months 2014, the company has announced upcoming activities for GTx-024 (Ostarine®; enobosarm), the company's lead product candidate for breast cancer. The ongoing Ph2 study of Capesaris® in CRPC is expected to complete enrollment by year-end, with top-line data expected in Q2:15. Management said it will evaluate the future development of Capesaris® after the data readout, including the potential for a partnership.
Highlights
Ph2 trial of enobosarm 9 mg for the treatment of patients with ER positive and AR positive metastatic breast cancer

Updated results from this trial have been accepted as a poster presentation at the San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium on December 10, 2014, in San Antonio, Texas. The results will be presented by the principal clinical investigator Dr. Beth A. Overmoyer, M.D., director of the Inflammatory Breast Cancer Program at the Susan F. Smith Center for Women’s Cancers at Dana Farber Cancer Institute, and assistant professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School.

The Company plans to commence, in the first half of 2015, 2 additional open-label Ph2 clinical trials of enobosarm;

- one in patients with ER positive and AR positive metastatic breast cancer - another in patients with advanced AR positive triple negative breast cancer.

The Company anticipates clinical data from the first stage of each of these Phase 2 clinical trials in the second half of 2016.

GTx-758 (Capesaris®) is being studied for secondary hormonal therapy in men with castration resistant prostate cancer and, potentially, as a secondary hormonal treatment for advanced prostate cancer used in combination with ADT

GTx continues to enroll patients in an open-label, Phase 2 clinical study of GTx-758 to treat men with metastatic and non-metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and is evaluating the safety and efficacy of two doses (125 mg and 250 mg) of GTx-758.

The Company has completed enrollment of the 125 mg arm and expects to complete enrollment in the 250 mg arm by the end of 2014.

item.title: Tivantinib Met Primary Endpoint Versus Placebo In a Ph2 Trial For mCRPC Patients [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Tivantinib Met Primary Endpoint Versus Placebo In a Ph2 Trial For mCRPC Patients [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Tivantinib Met Primary Endpoint Versus Placebo In a Ph2 Trial For mCRPC Patients [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10094 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 11 November 2014 | 15:30

Comment: ArQule announced positive topline Ph2 results for tivantinib (a MET inhibitor) as a single agent in men with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer. Tivantinib is co-developed and co-commercialised by ArQule and Daiichi Sankyo. Prostate cancer was not the focus of the development plan for both companies, and therefore this trial was initially conducted under a Cooperative Research and Development Agreement with the NCI's Cancer therapy evaluation programme. The trial has now met its primary endpoint of improving median PFS with tivantinib alone and versus placebo. Both companies are under discussion with the NCI for the potential to warrant additional trials in prostate cancer. The details analyses will be presented in future conferences by the principal investigator (the details of the conference has yet to disclose).
Clinicaltrials.gov Identifier NCT01519414
Number of patients = 78
Principal Investigator Dr. J.Paul Monk (Ohio State University) & Dr. Arthur G. James (Cancer Hospital and Solove Research Institute)
Trial Design: A randomized (2:1), double-blind, placebo controlled Ph2 Study (NCI Protocol #8986)
This study is a randomized Phase 2 trial in which men with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic metastatic castrate resistant, chemotherapy-naïve prostate cancer were randomized 2 to 1 to receive tivantinib 360 milligrams BID or placebo. The primary objective of the trial is PFS. Secondary objectives include PSA response rate at 12 weeks, radiographic response rate at 12 weeks, proportion of patients who are progression-free at 12 weeks, and safety and tolerability.
The study is designed to detect an improvement in the median PFS from 3 months to 6 months with tivantinib treatment. The proposed sample of 78 patients (26 in the placebo arm, 52 in the Tivantinib arm) provides 90% power to detect an improvement from 3 months median PFS with placebo to a median PFS of at least 6 months with tivantinib. This design is based on the assumption of having 58 cumulative events (progressions or deaths).
During ArQule Q3 2014 Financial Results Presentation, it is clear that the company's focus for Tivantinib at this point remains in its HCC development programme. ArQule aims to complete patient accrual in the Ph3 METIV-HCC trial by the end of 2015.
Source: ArQule Company Press Release

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jew60237

item.title: Dendreon Is In Chapter 11 - Dendreon's Share Fell 75% After Filing For Bankruptcy [dis:Prostate, headline]
item.description: Dendreon Is In Chapter 11 - Dendreon's Share Fell 75% After Filing For Bankruptcy [dis:Prostate, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Dendreon Is In Chapter 11 - Dendreon's Share Fell 75% After Filing For Bankruptcy [:Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:headline]
Oncology10091 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 11 November 2014 | 12:22

Comment: Dendreon has filed for voluntary federal bankruptcy protection and has reached an agreement with holders of $620 million in convertible debt. The company filed for Chapter 11 with $100 million in cash or cash equivalents, and won't need bankruptcy financing. As of the period ended 30th Sept 2014, Dendreon had $340 million in assets and $660.7 million in liabilities on a book value basis. Cost -containment efforts have reduced from 1,500 employees to the workforce of 698 people. Dendreon will pursue sale or reorganization in bankruptcy. Unless a buyer can be found that is willing to continue producing Provenge, the ownership of Dedreon and Provenge will default back to the lenders. Dendreon combined undue optimism in sales projections with excessive risk in its capital structure. It is a case of moderate product success and immoderate management failure. However, the fall out over Provenge's promise versus performance still lingers - as speculation of leakage information from Medicare/Medicaid Insurance Services to hands of investors is being investigated.
When Provenge won approval from the Food and Drug Administration in April 2010, it was touted as ushering in a new era of treatments to marshal the immune system to fight cancer, with high hopes for a clear path to profit. With its stock at more than $55 a share in May 2010, Dendreon’s market capitalization topped $7.5 billion. Dendreon's stock fell 10% on 7th June 2010 - the same day officials of the agency that oversees billions in health care spending began discussing whether to set new coverage limits on the costly new prostate cancer treatment.. Dendreon will continue manufacture and supply Provenge while in Chapter 11 - with the support from investors (including one of the big holder Deerfield Management Company LP). The investors have agreed to convert their debt to equity in a reorganized company, unless bidders offer to buy the business. However, there has been no prospective buyers stepped up during a quiet market test last year.
At an average of $93,000 for a course of treatment that improved median survival by just over four months, Provenge wasn’t adopted readily by doctors. Thereafter coming along with strong waves of competition - Zytiga and Xtandi's approval, both were pills that were easy to prescribe and require no upfront investment for doctors in the US. One analyst reports a low market share of Provenge under 5% recently and Dendreon's share fell as much as 74.5% to 24 cents on 10th Nov 2014. The lack of efficiencies in the manufacturing process is the main barrier for Dendreon to make a comeback as a standalone company. Also the emergence of Bavarian Nordic's experimental prostate cancer vaccine - that is cheaper to manufacture - could also spell the end of Provenge.
Source: Wall Street Journal, Reuters

Comments
Comment: Dendreon will hold an auction for bidders on 3rd Feb 2015 with a $275 million minimum bid requirement. Unless the company sells for enough to repay its $620 million in notes and other creditors, shareholders are unlikely to receive anything from the bankruptcy. Dendreon said in court documents that more than 40 parties had signed nondisclosure agreements, indicating interest in bidding on the company's assets. If the company does not hold an auction, Dendreon will emerge from bankruptcy under the control of noteholders. Those investors include funds associated with Deerfield Management Co, Aristeria Capital, Empyrean Capital Partners, Wolverine Asset Management and Partner Fund Management. (Source: Reuters US)
Jenny Wu / Oncology10199 / 09 January 2015 / 10:00:33 o'clock CET

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jew60237

item.title: Olaparib, AstraZeneca's PARP Inhibitor, Showed Promise In Prostate Cancer [dis:Prostate, comp:AstraZeneca]
item.description: Olaparib, AstraZeneca's PARP Inhibitor, Showed Promise In Prostate Cancer [dis:Prostate, comp:AstraZeneca]
item.content:encoded:
Olaparib, AstraZeneca's PARP Inhibitor, Showed Promise In Prostate Cancer [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10090 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 10 November 2014 | 16:32

Comment: Professor Johann de Bono presented data in NCRI Cancer Conference in Liverpool (the biggest oncology annual national conference in UK) and said some patients with advanced aggressive prostate cancer were having impressive responses to PARP inhibitor treatment. Olaparib could be effective against prostate tumours that harboured BRCA gene mutations. The first part of a phase II trial called TO-PARP, led by researchers at The Institute of Cancer Research, London and The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust, has assessed olaparib in advanced prostate cancer.
Currently, AstraZeneca has forecasted olaparib's market potential to $2 billion a year, however, only taking into account its promise in ovarian, breast, and gastric cancer. This is the first time when the experts highlighting the promise of PARP inhibitor in prostate cancer. However, it is still too early to tell if this preliminary result could translate into future success.
Source: conference.ncri.o…

item.dc:creator: jew60237

item.title: Orphan Drug Status For Auspex's PhIII Huntington's Disease Drug [dis:Huntington]
item.description: Orphan Drug Status For Auspex's PhIII Huntington's Disease Drug [dis:Huntington]
item.content:encoded:
Orphan Drug Status For Auspex's PhIII Huntington's Disease Drug [:Neurology:dis:Huntington]
Neurology7810 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 07 November 2014 | 16:50

Comment: Auspex Pharmaceuticals, today announced that the U.S. FDA has granted orphan drug designation of Auspex's investigational compound SD-809 for treatment of Huntington's disease.
Current Status of SD-809
Auspex is currently evaluating the efficacy and safety of SD-809 for treating chorea associated with this disorder in a Phase 3 registration clinical trial and is on track to announce topline data from this study in December 2014.
Commenting on this development Pratik Shah President & CEO of Auspex noted
"The orphan drug designation of SD-809 marks a major regulatory milestone for Auspex and a significant step forward in our goal to bring this novel treatment approach to patients as quickly as possible. Huntington's disease is a rare and devastating genetic disorder with very limited treatment options. The orphan drug designation recognizes the significant need that exists among individuals living with this disease."
Addtionally, Auspex is investing in the broad potential of SD-809 for the treatment of other movement disorders, including tardive dyskinesia and tics associated with Tourette syndrome.
SD-809's Profile Of Activity
Tetrabenazine (marketed as Xenazine® in the United States) is the only therapy approved by the U.S. FDA, for this indication. Auspex using its deuterium technology, has made chemical modifications at specific positions in the tetrabenazine molecule to create the novel drug candidate SD-809 (dutetrabenazine). Deuterium is a non-toxic, naturally occurring form of hydrogen. The substitution of deuterium (2H) for hydrogen (1H) at specific positions, in the case of SD-809, attenuates the breakdown of the drug’s active metabolites resulting in a differentiated pharmacokinetic profile compared to tetrabenazine.
This profile should enable less frequent dosing, improved tolerability, reduced interpatient variability in drug metabolism, as well as reduced drug interactions and reduced need for genotyping for drug-metabolizing enzymes.
Source: www.auspex.com

item.title: New IND Sumbitted To Investigate Immunomodulatory Doublet Therapy In mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.description: New IND Sumbitted To Investigate Immunomodulatory Doublet Therapy In mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
New IND Sumbitted To Investigate Immunomodulatory Doublet Therapy In mCRPC [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10089 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 07 November 2014 | 15:42

Comment: Advaxis - a US based biotechnology - has sumbitted an investigational new drug IND application to FDA for first in human trial of its ADXS31-142 in combination with MSD's anti-PD1 - Pembrolizumab - for mCRPC patients. The open label Ph1/2 trial is expected to initiate in Q1 2015 and will be jointly overseen by Advaxis and Merck. The Ph1 part will explore the recommended dose for ADXS31-142 as monotherapy and in combination with Pembrolizumab. The Phase II part will evaluate efficacy and safety of the combination strategy, both of which inhibit immunosuppression in tumour microenvioronment.
The Advaxis platform technology uses live, attenuated bioengineered Listeria monocytogenes (Lm) and then add multiple copies of a plasmid that encodes a fusion protein sequence including a fragment of the LLO (listeriolysin O) molecule joined to the antigen of interest. This fusion protein is secreted by the Listeria inside the antigen presenting cells, and other cells, which has been shown to result in a stimulation of both the innate and adaptive arms of the immune system and the potential reduction in tumor defense mechanisms. AXS31-142 is one of the lead compound from this platform and is designed to target the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) specifically. It secretes the PSA antigen, fused to the powerful immunostimulant tLLO, directly inside the antigen presenting cells that are capable of driving a cellular immune response to PSA expressing cells. This approach inhibits the Treg and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) that contribute to immunologic tolerance of prostate cancer. In preclinical analysis, ADXS-PSA inhibits the immunosuppression caused by Treg and MDSC cells localized inside tumors that may promote immunologic tolerance of prostate cancer.
DXS-HPV, another Advaxis's lead immunotherapy for the treatment of HPV-associated cancers, has demonstrated improved survival and objective tumor responses in a Phase 2 trial in 110 patients with recurrent cervical cancer. Advaxis is now planning the registrational program for ADXS-HPV. ADXS-HPV is also being evaluated in other HPV-associated cancers including a Phase 2 in advanced cervical cancer, a Phase 1/2 in head and neck cancer, and a Phase 1/2 in anal cancer. ADXS-HPV has orphan drug status for both anal and head and neck cancers. As part of its global commercialization strategy to enter into regional licensing deals with other market dominant biopharmaceutical companies in territories where there is a high prevalence of HPV-associated cancers, Advaxis has granted exclusive licenses for the development and commercialization of ADXS-HPV in Asia and India
Source: http:.//www.advaxis.com/technology/platform-technology

item.title: Macimorelin NDA Is Not Approvable For The Diagnosis Of AGHD [class:GrowthHormone, news]
item.description: Macimorelin NDA Is Not Approvable For The Diagnosis Of AGHD [class:GrowthHormone, news]
item.content:encoded:
Macimorelin NDA Is Not Approvable For The Diagnosis Of AGHD [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone, :Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7853 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 07 November 2014 | 14:24

Comment: Aeterna Zentaris has announced that it has received a Complete Response Letter from the US FDA regarding its NDA for MacrilenTM (macimorelin), a novel orally-active ghrelin agonist, for use in evaluating adult growth hormone deficiency. Based on its review, the FDA has determined that the NDA cannot be approved in its present form.
The FDA's Key Concerns

The CRL mentions that the planned analysis of the Company's pivotal trial did not meet its stated primary efficacy objective as agreed to in the Special Protocol Assessment agreement letter between the Company and the FDA.
The CRL further mentioned issues related to the lack of complete and verifiable source data for determining whether patients were accurately diagnosed with AGHD.
The FDA concluded that, “in light of the failed primary analysis and data deficiencies noted, the clinical trial does not by itself support the indication.”
To address the deficiencies the FDA has stated that a new confirmatory diagnostic trial will be required.
Safety Issue Also Of Concern
The CRL also outlined that a serious event of electrocardiogram QT interval prolongation occurred for which attribution to drug could not be excluded. Therefore a dedicated thorough QT study to evaluate the effect of macimorelin on the QT interval would be necessary.
Next Steps

David Dodd, Chairman and CEO at Aeterna Zentaris said, “Following the FDA's decision, we are currently reviewing the outstanding issues stated in the CRL in order to evaluate our options and future plans for MacrilenTM.”
Source: www.aezsinc.com

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Caring For Carcinoid Foundation Launches New Immunotherapy Initiative To Try & Improve Treatment Options [dis:MidGutNET, dis:pNET, Alert]
item.description: Caring For Carcinoid Foundation Launches New Immunotherapy Initiative To Try & Improve Treatment Options [dis:MidGutNET, dis:pNET, Alert]
item.content:encoded:
Caring For Carcinoid Foundation Launches New Immunotherapy Initiative To Try & Improve Treatment Options [:Endocrinology:Alert, :Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET]
Endocrinology7850 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 07 November 2014 | 14:13

Comment. The Caring for Carcinoid Foundation (CFCF) has announced the launch of a major immunotherapy initiative. Based on the dramatic results seen with immunotherapy for some other forms of cancer it is eager to test the potential of immune-based therapy to provide similar breakthroughs for patients with neuroendocrine cancers.
What Does The Initiative Involve?
The Caring for Carcinoid Foundation’s strategy brings leading experts - who have been involved in immunotherapy breakthroughs for other forms of cancer - to the cause of developing better treatments and cures for neuroendocrine cancers. Aclinical trial for the two major forms of NET pancreatic and gastrointestinal carcinoid is planned.
Source Of Funding
Ron Hollander, Executive Director of the Caring for Carcinoid Foundation, announced that CFCF has received a grant of $1 million to support half of the projected cost of the initial projects in this program. “We feel a real sense of urgency to test the potential of immunotherapy to provide treatment breakthroughs for NETs,” said Ron. He continued “The grant from the TripAdvisor Charitable Foundation serves as a challenge to CFCF and the entire NET community to rapidly raise the remaining $1 million to pursue these exciting projects. We are so grateful for the foundation's commitment and couldn't be more excited about this initiative."
The Priority Projects
1) The teams that developed a breakthrough immunotherapy technology will specifically target neuroendocrine tumors. Leading immunotherapy expert Dr. Carl June, and neuroendocrine tumor researcher Dr. Xianxin Hua, both from the University of Pennsylvania will modify CAR T-cells to target and kill neuroendocrine tumor cells, a method that has had dramatic results in patients with other cancers.
2) A clinical trial will evaluate two immunotherapy therapies in pancreatic and carcinoid neuroendocrine patients. This project includes a multidisciplinary team led by Dr. Pamela Kunz from Stanford University. An innovative delivery technique will also be tested to reduce the risk of adverse effects.
3) The third project will evaluate the immune characteristics of neuroendocrine tumors to guide CFCF's testing of immunotherapy treatments. CFCF is inviting immunology experts to systematically characterize neuroendocrine tumors’ immune features and genomes, and multiple grants will be awarded to study and profile these tumors.
The attached poster highlights the initiative.
Source: wwwcaringforcarcinoid.com
  1. Immunotherapy One Pager.pdf  (168,2 KB)

item.title: Bioniche Disappointed By Lack Of ODD For Its Bladder Cancer Therapy [dis:Bladder]
item.description: Bioniche Disappointed By Lack Of ODD For Its Bladder Cancer Therapy [dis:Bladder]
item.content:encoded:
Bioniche Disappointed By Lack Of ODD For Its Bladder Cancer Therapy [:Oncology:dis:Bladder]
Oncology10087 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 06 November 2014 | 19:11

Comment: Bioniche Life Sciences hasannounced that it will not continue its dialogue with the FDA concerning its request for Orphan Drug Designation (ODD) for its bladder cancer therapeutic MCNA.
FDA Questions The Size Of the Patient Population
The FDA has indicated that it could not grant Bioniche’s request for ODD at this time, because the Company had not established to its satisfaction that the target population estimate for MCNA did not exceed 200,000 potential patients in the US.
While the Company’s internal estimates put the addressable patient population for the treatment of the bladder cancer patient subset for which it will seek label designation (high-grade non-muscle invasive bladder cancer patients who have failed BCG therapy, i.e. BCG-refractory or BCG-relapsing) at less than 10,000 patients per year, the FDA requested additional data to support that MCNA would not be efficacious in low-grade bladder cancer. Given that the Company does not have the clinical or pre-clinical data to address this assertion, it is considered more productive to move forward with other fee waiver requests.
Source: www.bioniche.com
Commenting on this decision, Dr. Michael Berendt, Bioniche CEO and Chief Scientist, noted that:
“The ODD would have brought a single significant benefit to Bioniche, namely certain Biologics License Application (BLA) filing fee waivers totaling approximately $2.6 million. The other principal benefit of the designation, consisting of 7-year market exclusivity, is not required, as MCNA is a therapeutic biological product and will benefit from a longer 12-year market exclusivity upon approval, under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act's Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act.
He also noted that in anticipation of this potential decision, fee waiver requests have been made under two additional separate programs to which a positive response is expected from one or both prior to BLA filing in Q115.

item.title: After Re-priortising Its Portfolio GP Pharm Teams Up With A US Development Partner For Octreotide LAR [prod:Octreotide]
item.description: After Re-priortising Its Portfolio GP Pharm Teams Up With A US Development Partner For Octreotide LAR [prod:Octreotide]
item.content:encoded:
After Re-priortising Its Portfolio GP Pharm Teams Up With A US Development Partner For Octreotide LAR [:Endocrinology:prod:Octreotide]
Endocrinology7849 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 06 November 2014 | 19:02

Comment: Recent external intelligence has confirmed that the development of GP Pharm’s octreotide LAR will now move forward with an undisclosed top 30 US-based pharmaceutical/generic company.
Animal testing of the GP Pharm formulation is to be revisited by the partner and is expected to start soon.
The drug is scheduled to move into human trials by 2H2015 with the partner running those trials. The partner will be responsible for development in the US, EU, Russia, and Brazil, whilst GP Pharm will retain rights in South America excl Brazil. The partner is reportedly working towards a US approval in Q217.
GP Pharm's financial resource and development capability was impacted by the sale of its parent company to Lubrizol in 2012, as it was excluded from the transaction at that time.
It continues to prioritise the geographic availability of different formulations of Luprolide (1 and 3 months) whilst looking for partners for other product development programmes.
With regard to the identity of the potential US partner one approach could be to consider the "Orange book" listings of US companies already marketing the immediate release form. A top 30 US-based pharmaceutical companies amongst this list is Mylan. Outside of this listing other top 30 companies that could logically be considered are Pfizer, Hospira and Amgen.
If anybody learns more about this potential partnership through local sources, please do share the information with the ENDO Franchise or the Business Intelligence Unit.

item.title: AstraZeneca Q3 Financial Results Key Takeaway - Progress In Immuno-Oncology [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca]
item.description: AstraZeneca Q3 Financial Results Key Takeaway - Progress In Immuno-Oncology [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca]
item.content:encoded:
AstraZeneca Q3 Financial Results Key Takeaway - Progress In Immuno-Oncology [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca]
PharmaWorld11010 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 06 November 2014 | 18:50

Comment: AstraZeneca today released their Q3 2014 financial result - AZ now expects sales to grow in low single digits at constant exchange rate this year (as previous prediction is that AZ's sales should remain flat this year). Chief Executive Pascal Soriot, said he would use the better financial outlook to speed up investment in the company's promising pipeline of new drugs. In the eyes of analysts, however, AZ still has a lot to demonstrate despite of the proven pipeline momentum - in particular, immuno-oncology is one of AZ's focus area. During the presentation, it appears that current AZ's PD-1 development programmes are focusing on NSCLC, and Head & Neck Cancer. AZ's business development focus is aimed to supplement its strategic priorities. One of which being highlighted in oncology is the recent deal to partner with J&J and Pharmacyclics that will supplement and expand its current P-1 portfolio to haematological cancers. The big question still yet to be demonstrated is if AZ is able to deliver the promise given the strong competitions with rivals such as BMS, MSD, and Roche in the horizon.
Source: AstraZeneca.com

item.title: Court Ruling Supportive of Valeant's Fight For Allergan
item.description: Court Ruling Supportive of Valeant's Fight For Allergan
item.content:encoded:
Court Ruling Supportive of Valeant's Fight For Allergan
Neurology7807 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 05 November 2014 | 11:19

Comment: Yesterday Bill Ackmann one a significant victory in his battle to force Allergan to sell itself to Valeant, when a court denied Allergan's request to prevent Pershing from voting its 10% stake at a shareholder meeting on December 18th.This ruling makes it easier for Mr Ackman and Valeant to win enough investor support to replace the majority of the Allergan board.
Allergan not pleased by this ruling is reportedly to file an emergency appeal.
Judge Carter calimed that the court needed to be "neutral and to leave decisions regarding a company's future and management in the hands of shareholders".
Meanwhile, the potential rival bidder for Allergan, noted in the company's security filing. remains undisclosed but is believed to be Actavis.

Source: Financial Times

item.title: Expanded Clinical Development Of Laquinimod [dis:Huntington]
item.description: Expanded Clinical Development Of Laquinimod [dis:Huntington]
item.content:encoded:
Expanded Clinical Development Of Laquinimod [:Neurology:dis:Huntington]
Neurology7806 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 05 November 2014 | 11:03

Comment: Teva Pharmaceuticals and its partner Active Biotech have announced the expansion of the laquinimod clinical development program with the initiation of the ARPEGGIO trial, to treat primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). Additionally, Teva has also screened the first patient in the LEGATO-HD trial, which will evaluate laquinimod in Huntington’s disease. Commenting on this development Michael Hayden, M.D., Ph.D., President of Global R&D and Chief Scientific Officer at Teva Pharmaceuticals noted “Laquinimod has been shown to modulate several significant pathways common to key neurodegenerative disease. More specifically, it modulates the immune cell lineages in the periphery and in the CNS. We look forward to the results from both of these studies.”
Study Designs
The ARPEGGIO study will evaluate the efficacy, safety and tolerability of laquinimod in patients with PPMS with a primary endpoint of percent brain volume change (PBVC) through MRI analysis. Approximately 15 percent of MS patients fall into the PPMS category.
The LEGATO-HD study will evaluate the efficacy, safety and tolerability of once-daily oral laquinimod as a potential treatment for adult patients with Huntington’s disease. The primary endpoint for LEGATO-HD is change from baseline in the Unified Huntington’s Disease Rating Scale-Total Motor Scale (UHDRS-TMS) as defined by the sum of the scores of all UHDRS-TMS sub-items after 12 months of treatment.
Source: www.tevapharm.com

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Exelixis Business Update - Good Progress With COMETRIQ But Awaiting CRPC Results From COMET-2 [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Exelixis Business Update - Good Progress With COMETRIQ But Awaiting CRPC Results From COMET-2 [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Exelixis Business Update - Good Progress With COMETRIQ But Awaiting CRPC Results From COMET-2 [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10086 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 05 November 2014 | 09:38

Comment: Net revenue for the quarter was $6.3 million, consisting entirely of product revenue from the sale of COMETRIQ for medullary thyroid cancer. From an R&D perspective, the group reported final overall survival results from the EXAM study, timelines for readouts of the CRPC COMET-2 study and the ongoing enrollment status of its renal cell & HCC studies. With $200m in cash the group has sufficient financial resources to support its business throughout 2015.
Excluding the $1.8m project management fee Exelixis had to pay its European partner SOBI net sales of COMETRIQ in the quarter increased by 32% vs last year. Sales growth in the US was driven by ioncreases in treated patients as well as extended treatment duration. Total operating expenses for the quarter were $57.9 million. The decrease of $3.5 million as compared to Q3 last year reflects the changes in R&D ($43.6m vs.$47.4m) and SG&A ($9.9m vs $13.6m) offset by the increases to the restructuring expenses ($3.8m).
Trial Update
COMET-2, Exelixis second Phase 3 study in CRPC stopped patient enrollment in September with top line data now expected before the end of this year. This study is assessing pain response comparing cabozantinib versus mitoxantrone prednisone and metastatic CRPC patients who have previously received docetaxel and abiraterone and/or enzalutamide, and are suffering from moderate-to-severe pain due to metastatic bone lesions despite narcotic medication. Once all data from COMET-1 and COMET-2 are available, the company will formulate its regulatory strategy for CRPC, if any

EXAM Exelixis's Phase 3 study in patients with progressive unresectable locally advanced or metastatic medullary thyroid cancer that compared cabozantinib versus placebo led to the full regulatory approval of COMETRIQ for patients with progressive metastatic MTC in the United States in late 2012 and to conditional approval in the EU in early 2014. The approvals were based on the results of the primary endpoint of progression-free survival, showing a 2.8 fold longer median progression-free survival for the cabozantinib arm compared to placebo.

At the time of the PFS analysis in October 2011, the study was unblinded and placebo patients were allowed to receive other available therapies. Overall survival a secondary endpoint that was to be analyzed once a total of 217 death events have been reached. With an additional three years of follow up, the 217 death events required for the analysis have recently being reached and top line final results for OS are now available.
These data are in line with what has been previously seen in an interim analysis for overall survival in 2012. The estimated median overall survival for the cabozantinib arm was 26.6 month and 21.1 months for the placebo arm, for an HR of 0.85 and a p value of 0.2409, which is not statistically significant.
Management noted that given the rare patient population, the study overall was relatively small for the assessment of overall survival. The study had 80% power to detect a 50% improvement in overall survival risk statistical significance. Additionally, more placebo patients than cabozantinib patients received subsequent anticancer treatments.
However, the subset analysis among subjects positive for RET M918T mutation showed a large and statistically significant overall survival benefit of 25.4 months with median overall survival for the cabozantinib arm of 44.3 months and a median overall survival for the placebo arm of 18.9 months, for an HR of 0.6 and a p value of 0.026. Exelixis intends to submit this data to both the U.S. FDA and EMA in the first half of 2015 as part of its post-marketing commitment. This may potentially lead to label updates in the future.

The CELESTIAL trial in second-line HCC patients, who received prior sorafenib comparing cabozantinib versus placebo, is also proceeding well. It is actively enrolling globally and is designed to enroll 760 patients randomized in a 2 to 1 ratio to cabozantinib versus placebo and the primary endpoint is overall survival.

Enrollment in METEOR, Exelixis's Phase 3 pivotal trial in metastatic second-line RCC, is nearly complete. The group is now confident that the enrollment goal of 650 patients will be met in the coming days. Top line results for the trial’s primary endpoint, progression fee survival is now expected in the second quarter of 2015.
Source: exelixis.com

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: New Endocrine Society Guideline For The Diagnosis & Treatment Of Acromegaly [dis:Acromegaly]
item.description: New Endocrine Society Guideline For The Diagnosis & Treatment Of Acromegaly [dis:Acromegaly]
item.content:encoded:
New Endocrine Society Guideline For The Diagnosis & Treatment Of Acromegaly [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly]
Endocrinology7848 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 04 November 2014 | 19:32

Comment: Last Friday the Endocrine Society issued a Clinical Practice Guideline for the diagnosis and treatment of acromegaly. This appears in the November 2014 issue of the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism. Tumout removal is reccommended as first-line treatment.
In the CPG, the Endocrine Society recommends that surgery to remove tumours from the pituitary gland be considered as the primary therapy for most patients. Successful surgery has the advantage of immediately lowering growth hormone levels. Five-year disease recurrence rates are small, ranging from 2% to 8%. This approach also provides an opportunity to examine the tumour sample to learn more about the individual’s condition.
When acromegaly symptoms persist after surgery, the Endocrine Society recommends pursuing medical therapy. Some patients may require radiation therapy if there is tumour tissue remaining after surgery or in cases where medication is ineffective or causes side effects.
Other recommendations from the CPG include:
• IGF-1 levels should be measured in people who have facial features or large extremities associated with acromegaly.
• When a person has a mass on the pituitary gland, IGF-1 levels should be measured to rule out acromegaly.
• Physicians should not rely on random growth hormone measurements to diagnose the condition.
• An acromegaly diagnosis should be confirmed by testing whether the body continues to produce growth hormone after the patient drinks sugar water for an oral glucose tolerance test.
• People with acromegaly should be assessed to see whether the pituitary tumour has caused damage and created a deficiency of other pituitary hormones, a condition called hypopituitarism.
• After surgery to remove the pituitary tumour, an imaging study (usually an MRI) to visualise any residual tumour tissue should be conducted at least 12 weeks later.
• Patients receiving radiation therapy should undergo annual growth hormone and IGF-1 reassessments after medication withdrawal.
• People who develop gigantism as children also should be treated using surgery as the primary therapy, and then using medication or radiation treatment based on the individual'’ condition and response to treatment.
SOURCE: The Endocrine Society

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Cortendo Changes Course & Targets US IPO [dis:Cushing]
item.description: Cortendo Changes Course & Targets US IPO [dis:Cushing]
item.content:encoded:
Cortendo Changes Course & Targets US IPO [:Endocrinology:dis:Cushing]
Endocrinology7847 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 04 November 2014 | 18:43

Comment In an attempt to inject capital into its business, Cortendo AB, has elected to sell approximately 19.3 million of its shares at $0.58 per share to its investors in a private placement. Assuming certain shareholder hurdles are overcome, Arctic Fund Management, Storebrand, the Third Swedish National Pension Fund, and HealthCap will finance Cortendo with approximately $11m. This bridge financing has triggered Cortendo to delist its publically traded shares from the Norwegian Over the Counter market and abandon its ambition of listing on the Oslo Stock Exchange.
Why The Change of Heart?
Instead, the drug developer plans to utilize some of this money to launch an initial public offering (IPO) in the US. Floating Cortendo on a US stock exchange will augment NormoCort’s recognition in that market, positioning the company well to successfully commercialize the drug in the US.
GlobalData's Perspective On The Market Opportunity For NormoCort
From a commercial standpoint, NormoCort has a large, target patient pool owing to the fact that the drug targets all CS subtypes. Its closest rival is generic ketoconazole, which represents the current gold standard of care, but, unlike its competitor, NormoCort is being prospectively evaluated in clinical trials exclusively in CS patients. Consequently, if approved, NormoCort will be much more readily available to US CS sufferers than ketoconazole is.
However, NormoCort’s expensive price tag, which GlobalData predicts will give it a US annual cost of therapy (ACOT) of $192,499, will likely impede the drug’s uptake. In comparison, generic ketoconazole has an ACOT of approximately $3,942.
One Key Opinion Leader interviewed by GlobalData reiterated this concern, stating that, due to current economic restraints, NormoCort’s adoption into clinical practice will depend on its price. Furthermore, Cortendo’s small size, relatively unknown reputation, limited resources, and weak marketing and sales force strength will all detrimentally influence NormoCort’s performance.
GlobalData anticipates near-simultaneous launches of both NormoCort and Novartis’ LCI699, the new and improved version of HRA Pharma’s Metopirone (metyrapone), in the US market in 2018.
The Swiss drug developer’s pharmacological agent possesses clinical and commercial attributes that are superior to NormoCort, including being backed by a global pharmaceutical giant. Accordingly, GlobalData is led to believe that, despite Cortendo’s claim that NormoCort is safer and more efficacious than ketoconazole, LCI699 will muscle NormoCort out for patient share and will eventually surpass ketoconazole as the first-line medical therapy for CS patients.
Source: GlobalData

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Astellas and Proteostasis to Investigate Diseases Caused by Protein Defects [dis:Huntington, :Oncology:comp:Astellas]
item.description: Astellas and Proteostasis to Investigate Diseases Caused by Protein Defects [dis:Huntington, :Oncology:comp:Astellas]
item.content:encoded:
Astellas and Proteostasis to Investigate Diseases Caused by Protein Defects [:Neurology:dis:Huntington, :Oncology:comp:Astellas]
Neurology7804 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 04 November 2014 | 13:12

Comment: Astellas is licensing one project from Cambridge, Massachusetts-based Proteostasis for >$400m, and has taken an option on two more that could triple that investment. Specifically, the two companies will use Proteostasis' platform technology to modulate a cellular pathway known as the unfolded protein response (UPR), a stress response that tries to repair protein-folding defects and prevent accumulation of mis-folded proteins within cells. Along with Alzheimer's and CJD, disorders that involve a UPR component include Parkinson's and Huntington's disease.
Astellas Strategy
  • revamp approach to R&D, scaling back some traditional research areas
  • accelerate shift into biopharmaceuticals and vaccines
  • increase emphasis on emerging technoogies (such as regenerative medicine)
Proteostasis
Mini Profile
Proteostasis Therapeutics is developing disease-modifying therapeutics for orphan and neurodegenerative diseases.
The Company’s lead programs in Cystic Fibrosis (CF) and protein aggregation disorders such as Parkinson’s disease modulate protein chaperone and proteasomal degradation pathways within the cell.
These pathways are part of the cellular ‘quality control’ machinery, called the protein homeostasis network or Proteostasis Network (PN) that regulates protein folding, trafficking, and clearance. By enhancing the function and capacity of the PN, the Company’s product candidates correct for imbalances in the PN resulting from the cumulative effects of disease, genetic mutations, environmental factors, and aging. Platform
Partnerships
Dec. 2013 - Biogen Idec http://www.proteostasis.com/media/news/220-proteostasis-therapeutics-announces-collaboration-with-biogen-idec.html
May 2011 - Neurology5737: Elan And Proteostasis Form Drug Discovery Initiative in the Neurodegenerative Area
Source: Proteostasis

item.title: AstraZeneca Strengthens Its Immuno-Oncology Business By Focusing On Surrogate Biomarker Test And Combination Strategy For Its PD-1
item.description: AstraZeneca Strengthens Its Immuno-Oncology Business By Focusing On Surrogate Biomarker Test And Combination Strategy For Its PD-1
item.content:encoded:
AstraZeneca Strengthens Its Immuno-Oncology Business By Focusing On Surrogate Biomarker Test And Combination Strategy For Its PD-1
Oncology10084 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 04 November 2014 | 11:31

Comment: AstraZeneca has signed three deals with the intention to strengthen its current oncology portfolio. The collaboration includes an agreement to acquire Definiens (a private tissue diagnostic company) and two collaborations with J&J and Pharmacyclics to explore combination strategy with Imbruvica in haematological cancers. These colloaborations will extend its current reach in solid tumours (including lung cancer) into haematological cancers.
Definien's proprietary Cognition Network Technology® was developed by Professor Gerd Binning, the 1986 Nobel Laureate in Physics. The technology is aimed to unlock information from cancer tissue samples by measuring the identity, locations and most importantly the relationships between the many and varied components of the complex tumour microenvironment. Under the terms of the agreement, Medimmune will acquire 100% of Definiens' shares for an initial consideration of $ 150 million and make additional predetermined milestone payments. Definiens will continue to operate its business with third party customers.

Source: AstraZeneca Press Release

item.content:encoded:
Undisclosed Company Interested in Buying Allergan [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :Neurology:news]
Neurology7800 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 04 November 2014 | 09:27

Comment: In a regulatory filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), Allergan has reported having being approached by 'another party' regarding a potential transaction. Reuters reported in early October that Actavis, which had already reached out to Allergan once in the prior months, was planning a second approach to the company with an offer worth more than $200 per share.
Management said in the filing that " ... Our board has determined that premature disclosure with respect to the possible terms of any transaction might jeopardize continuation of any discussions or negotiations".
Source: Allergan;LA Times; Reuters

item.title: Ph3 MAESTRO Pancreatic Trial Fully Enrolled [news]
item.description: Ph3 MAESTRO Pancreatic Trial Fully Enrolled [news]
item.content:encoded:
Ph3 MAESTRO Pancreatic Trial Fully Enrolled [:Oncology:news]
Oncology10080 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 November 2014 | 16:00

Comment: Merck has announced completion of target enrollment of 660 patients. The study is being conducted under a SPA and compares TH-302/gemcitabine with gemcitabine alone. The primary overall survival endpoint of this study is event driven and management is currently guiding to completion in 1Q:16, with top-line results being reported shortly thereafter.
About the MAESTRO Trial
MAESTRO is a randomized, placebo-controlled, international, multi-center, double-blind Phase 3 trial of TH-302 plus gemcitabine compared with placebo plus gemcitabine.
The primary efficacy endpoint is overall survival; the secondary endpoints include efficacy measured by progression-free survival (PFS), overall response rate and disease control rate, as well as assessments of safety and tolerability, pharmacokinetics and biomarkers.
The study is being conducted under a Special Protocol Assessment (SPA) agreement with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The study design was also discussed with the European Medicines Agency (EMA) during a scientific advice procedure
See Oncology8746: Threshold and Merck KGaA Progress with Their Pancreatic Cancer Program
Hypoxia-Targeted Drug TH-302
Drug Development Programs

item.title: Nymox Drug Did Not Produce Intended Results [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Nymox Drug Did Not Produce Intended Results [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Nymox Drug Did Not Produce Intended Results [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10078 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 November 2014 | 12:35

Comment: Nymox has reported that two ph3 studies of NX-1207, “failed to meet their primary efficacy endpoints". According to the company website, the drug, a treatment for an enlarged prostate that can restrict the flow of urine from the bladder, has been the pharmaceutical company’s most promising drug.
BPH Trials
NX02-0017 and NX02-0018, failed to meet their primary efficacy endpoints.
Prostate Cancer
The drug remains promising for low-grade localised prostate cancer” where Ph2 results showed evidence that NX-1207 had “a positive effect on biopsy results and clinical and biochemical progression”.
Partnership
The drug is partnered with Recordati, which holds European and other non-US rights to the drug in BPH.
Consequences
Nymox’s shares fell 1.5 percent to $5.14 on Oct. 31.

Comment: Users can create a 3D image of the potential results of Juvederm(R) facial filler, showing all angle sof their face. The technology will allow consumers to visualize what they could look like if treated with the facial filler in full 3D.
About the Application
Powered by ModiFace
Objectives: to stimlulate the effects of Juverderm(R) facial filler by creating a 3D image of the user's face.
Features
  • Upload a photo to produce a 3D image of your face that can be rotated and viewed from all angles
  • Apply and adjust more than 10 Juvederm(R) treatment effects
  • View and share virtual "Before" and "After" pictures with friends and/or a doctor.
Source: Allergan Canada; ModiFace

How can the authorities allow this there is no way of checking in advance that the treatment will have that effect. Doesn't promotional material generally have to be approved in advance by most authorities?

Selected Figures

  • exports of W250mn (to Thailand) - see Neurology7612: Update of Daewoong's Nabota in Thailand
Situation in the US
Alphaeon, Daewoong Pharmaceutical’s US partner, announced that Evosyal (Nabota’s US brand) received investigational new drug (IND) approval from the FDA in September (with patient recruitment for clinical trials taking place by the end of this year).
  • Analyst with Mirae Asset expect Nabota to be released in the US in 2017, following the likely completion of Phase IIIa clinical trials in 2015 (source: report issues on Oct 14 2014).

item.title: Astellas/Medivation Is To Initiate Ph3 Study To Envaluate Enzalutamide In M0 CRPC Patients [dis:Prostate, comp:Astellas]
item.description: Astellas/Medivation Is To Initiate Ph3 Study To Envaluate Enzalutamide In M0 CRPC Patients [dis:Prostate, comp:Astellas]
item.content:encoded:
Astellas/Medivation Is To Initiate Ph3 Study To Envaluate Enzalutamide In M0 CRPC Patients [:Oncology:comp:Astellas, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology10075 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 31 October 2014 | 19:48

Comment: Astellas and Medivation announced initiation of Global Ph3 Enzalutamide trial in M0 CRPC patients with the objective to evaluate the efficacy and safety of enzalutamide. Currrently there is no approved treatment in this setting. The trial is aimed to enroll 1,860 patients from 160 sites and randomized into three arms : enzalutamide monotherapy vs placebo + leuprolide vs enzalutamide + leuprolide.
During the press release, Lynn Seely (CMO, Medivation) said " one third of men in the United States experience a rising PSA, also known as biochemical recurrence, after localized therapy for the treatment of prostate cancer. This trial will determine if enzalutamide can delay the development of metastatic prostate cancer in high-risk men with a rapidly rising PSA"
Source: Astellas/Medivation Press Release

item.title: Registration Trial of Lanzhou Institute's Botulinum Toxin Type A for Post-Stroke ULS in China [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Registration Trial of Lanzhou Institute's Botulinum Toxin Type A for Post-Stroke ULS in China [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Registration Trial of Lanzhou Institute's Botulinum Toxin Type A for Post-Stroke ULS in China [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Neurology7793 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 31 October 2014 | 17:12

Comment: According to clinicaltrials.gov, the Ph3 RCT started in Q3:14, and is designed to compare HengLi® with placebo on the efficacy and safety of treatment in post-stroke subjects with focal wrist, finger and in some cases, thumb spasticity. Approximately 180 subjects will be enrolled. PE will measure change from baseline at wk6 of wrist flexor muscle tone.
Trial Details
Reference NCT02280083
Timelines completion expected Nov 2015 / Jan 2016
Intervention
Subjects will receive a single treatment session of intramuscular HengLi® 200U or 240U (if thumb spasticity is present) or placebo after they first enroll the core phase randomly. Totally 180 subjects will be recruited in this part.
Each completed subject should finish 8 (visit 0 to 7) clinic visits. Subjects will receive a single intramuscular treatment with either HengLi® or placebo at day 0 (visit 0). The else 7 visits are at week 1, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16 and 18 (visits 1 to 7) and week 6 (visit 3) is appointed as the primary visit to determine efficacy.
Principal Investigator
Shengyuan Yu (The General Hospital of People's Liberation Army(301 hospital)

Results
Non-Core Assets Divested/Deprioritized
Focused Pipeline
30 launches are expected by 2019, with total of $4B in new revenue.

item.title: UEGW (Vienna) - Biocodex Sympo Focused on Cost-Effectiveness and New Insights of Saccharomyces Boulardii CNCM I-745 [news, :PharmaWorld:congress:UEGW]
item.description: UEGW (Vienna) - Biocodex Sympo Focused on Cost-Effectiveness and New Insights of Saccharomyces Boulardii CNCM I-745 [news, :PharmaWorld:congress:UEGW]
item.content:encoded:
UEGW (Vienna) - Biocodex Sympo Focused on Cost-Effectiveness and New Insights of Saccharomyces Boulardii CNCM I-745 [:GastroEnterology:news, :PharmaWorld:congress:UEGW]
GastroEnterology2112 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 31 October 2014 | 15:55

Comment: Introduced and chaired by Ph. Marteau (MD, PhD, head of the Unit of Digestive Disease, Lariboisière Hosp, and professor of gastroenterology Paris 7 University), the symposium started with the results from the first multinational survey on probiotics awareness, which was conducted by the International Study Group on Probiotics (ISGoP) in 10 countries. C. Kelly then provided recent data on the impact of CNCM I-745 on gut microbiota in AAD and CDI. The cost-effectiveness of using CNCM I-745 to reduce hospitalization was demonstrated by Ir. S. Vermeersch.
Take Home Messages from the ISGoP Survey
Material & Methods
Highlligts of the study:
  • Most physicians feel well informed about probiotics
  • There is an unclear definition of probiotic

- more recognized as bacteria than yeast

- no consensus on clinically proven strains

  • >50% recommend probiotics for AID and AAD
  • 2/3 use probiotics for their relatives or themselves
  • Positive perception on probiotics safety
  • Lack of information is a key obstacle for not prescribing probiotics
  • >89% read at least 1 article/year on probiotics
  • Continuous medical education on probiotics is key to promote awareness
Dr Ch Boggio Marzet (MD, Head of the Paediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition Section at Hospital General de Agudos) outlined that physicians knowledge in the field of probiotics is crucial for a full understanding of human microbiota in health and disease.
Key Findings on the Impact of CNCM I-745 on Gut Microbiota
Dr. Ciarán Kelly, Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School and Director of Gastroenterology Training at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and Dr. Toufic Kabbani, Gastroenterology fellow at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, utilized DNA technology to investigate the effects of Saccharomyces boulardii CNCM I-745 (Sb), and Amoxicillin/Clavulanate, and the combination on the microbiome of the healthy human GI tract, where 70% of our immune system resides.
Study Design
Results
Antibiotic treatment reduces Ralstonia and increases parabacteroides, escherischia/shighella in different genera
Key findings show the probiotic Sb can help to maintain and restore a healthy and balanced intestinal ecosystem.
Economic Evaluation of CNCM I-745
In a cost study based on a decision tree analysis (comparing the cost with/without preventive treatment with sb) for patients on antibiotic therapy, the economic impact of the preventive use of sb in adult hospitalized patients taking antibiotics was established.
S Vermeersch (computer science engineer) concluded that:
Full presentation of the Biocodex sympo is available on demand to Brigitte Deschamps
